The garden of the Krasińsk Palace is a popular place for varsians to walk with their benches, flower mats, duck ponds and playgrounds. Here is also the monument of Ghetto Uring, Warsaw. Özienki Park covers 76 hectares. The unique nature and history of the park are reflected in its landscape architecture (pavilions, sculptures, bridges, cascades, ponds) and vegetation (domestic and foreign species of wood and shrubs). This park is different from the other green areas of Warsaw, for there are peacocks and pheasants that appear here freely walking, and royal carps in the pond. paragraphs.context: The closely related fields of theoretical computer science are algorithm analysis and calculation theory. The key difference between algorithm analysis and computational complexity theory is that the first one analyses the amount of resources needed to solve a particular algorithm problem, while the second asks a more general question about all possible algorithms that could be used to solve the same problem. paragraphs.context: Some scholars have claimed that Luther taught that faith and reason are opposites in the sense that questions of faith could not be enlightened by reason. He wrote: "All the writings of our Christian faith, which God has revealed to us in his Word, are irrationally impossible, unreasonable and false." and "That reason in no way promotes faith. [...] The cause is the greatest enemy that faith has; it will never help spiritual things." Although he seems to be in conflict, he wrote in his latter work that human reason “is not contrary to faith when it is enlightened, but rather promotes and promotes it,” and claimed to be a fideist. However, a modern Lutheran scholarship has found a different reality in Luther. Rather, Luther seeks to distinguish between faith and reason in order to honor the spheres of knowledge to which everyone applies. For example, Bernhard Lohse, in his classic book Fides und Ratio, showed that Luther finally tried to combine these two. Recently, Hans-Peter Grosshans has shown that Luther’s Biblical criticism highlights the need for external consistency in the correct executable method. This means that for Luther it is more important that the Bible is reasonable according to the reality that does not belong to the scriptures than that the Bible is reasonable to itself that it has internal unity. For Luther, the right tool to understand the world outside the Bible is only reason, which is an area of science, philosophy, history, and empirical observation for him. Here is a different picture of Luther, who deeply appreciated both faith and reason and kept them in a dialectic partnership. Already in 1516 he wrote that many people “are proud of the wonderful foolishness of calling on Jewish dogs, evildoers or whatever they want, even though they do not realize who or what they are in God’s sight.” In 1523 Luther counseled kindness toward the Jews in the fact that Jesus Christ was born a Jew and also sought to convert them to Christianity. paragraphs.context: Before European settlements, Victoria now had a large number of Aboriginal people, commonly known as Koori. The first colony in the area took place in 1803 in Sullivan Bay, and much of the present Victoria was covered by Port Phillip in 1836, the administrative department of New South Wales. Victoria was officially established as a separate colony in 1851 and reached self - rule in 1855. The Victorian gold rush in the 1850s and 1860s significantly increased the population and wealth of the colony, and by the Australian Federation in 1901 Melbourne had become the largest city in Australasia and the leading financial centre. Melbourne also served as the capital of Australia until the construction of Canberra in 1927, when the Bundestag meeting in the Melbourne Parliament House and all the federal government headquarters were located in Melbourne.

Condensed hot water discharge from the condenser is put back into the boiler through the pump. The dry cooling tower resembles the car cooler and is used in places where the water is expensive. Volatile (wet) cooling towers use abandoned heat for evaporation of water; this water is kept separate from condensation that circulates in a closed system and returns to the boiler. Such towers often contain visible plums because steamed water condenses with drops raised by warm air. Volatile cooling towers need less water than "through" cooling of the river or lake water; a 700 megawatt coal power plant can use about 3600 cubic metres of make-up water per hour for evaporation cooling, but it needs about twenty times more if it cools down from the river water.[Obligation is necessary]

paragraphs.context: Although the European Union does not have a codified constitution, as is the case with all political bodies, it has laws that'make' its governance structure. The main constitutional sources of the EU are the Treaty on European Union and the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, which have been agreed or complied with by the governments of all 28 Member States. The Treaties establish the EU institutions, list their powers and responsibilities and explain the areas in which the EU can legislate by means of directives or regulations. The European Commission has an initiative for legislative proposals. During the normal legislative procedure, the Council (ministers of the governments of the Member States) and the European Parliament (chosen by the citizens) may make changes and must give their consent to the adoption of laws. The Commission supervises the services and agencies that implement or implement EU law. The "European Council" (i.e. the Council, composed of ministers from different governments) consists of the prime ministers or executive president of the Member States. It shall appoint the members of the Commission and the Executive Board of the European Central Bank. The Court of Justice of the European Communities is the supreme judicial body which interprets and develops EU law through a precedent. The Court of Justice may review the legality of the activities of the EU institutions in accordance with the Treaties. It can also decide on Member States’ and citizens’ demands for infringements of EU law.

paragraphs.context: The primary EU law consists mainly of the Treaties, the most important of which are the Treaty on European Union and the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. The Treaties contain formal and substantive provisions which guide the policies of the institutions of the European Union and determine the division of competences between the European Union and its Member States. The TEU provides that European Union law applies to the metropolitan areas of the Member States and to certain islands and overseas regions, such as Madeira, the Canary Islands and the French overseas departments. European Union legislation also applies in areas where a Member State is responsible for external relations, such as Gibraltar and Åland. The TEU will enable the European Council to issue specific provisions for regions such as Gibraltar and Saint-Pierre-et-Miquelon in customs matters. The TEU excludes certain regions, such as the Faroe Islands, from the jurisdiction of European Union law. The Treaties shall apply as soon as they enter into force, unless otherwise specified, and shall normally be concluded for an unlimited period. The TEU provides that commitments entered into between Member States prior to the signature of the Agreement are no longer valid. In accordance with the TEU, all EU Member States are considered to be the general obligation of the principle of cooperation to refrain from taking measures which could jeopardise the achievement of the objectives of the TEU. The Court of Justice of the European Union may interpret the Treaties but cannot decide on their validity under international law. Individuals may rely on the primary right before the Court of Justice of the European Union if the provisions of the Treaty have direct effect and are sufficiently clear, precise and unconditional.

paragraphs.context: The main agreements which form the European Union began with common rules for the coal and steel sector and then for nuclear energy, but more complete and formal institutions were established by the Treaty of Rome 1957 and the Maastricht Treaty in 1992 (now the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union). Minor changes were made in the 1960s and 1970s. Significant amending treaties were signed in order to complete the development of the single market in the Single European Act in 1986, to promote the development of a social Europe in the Treaty of Amsterdam in 1997 and to make minor changes to the relative power of the Member States in the EU institutions in the Treaty of Nice 2001 and in the Treaty of Lisbon 2007. Since its establishment, several Member States have joined through several accession treaties: Great Britain, Ireland, Denmark and Norway in 1972 (although Norway did not become a member), Greece in 1979, Spain and Portugal in 1985, Austria, Finland, Norway and Sweden in 1994 (although Norway missed accession following a referendum), the Czech Republic, Cyprus, Estonia, Hungary, Latvia, Lithuania, Malta, Poland, Slovakia and Slovenia in 2004, Romania and Bulgaria in 2007 and Croatia in 2013 respectively. Greenland signed an agreement in 1985 giving it a special status.

paragraphs.context: Following the Treaty of Nice, attempts were made to reform and make the European Constitution more transparent, which would also have produced a single Constitutional Act. However, following a referendum in France and a referendum in the Netherlands, the 2004 Treaty on the Constitution for Europe never entered into force. Instead, the Treaty of Lisbon was adopted. Its content was very similar to that of the proposed Constitutional Treaty, but it was formally an amending Treaty, and although it substantially changed existing treaties, it did not completely replace them.

paragraphs.context: The European Commission is the main executive body of the European Union. According to Article 17(1) of the Treaty on European Union, the Commission should 'promote the general interest of the Union', whereas Article 17(3) states that the members of the Commission should be 'fully independent' and not 'take instructions from any government'. Article 17(2) states that 'a Union act may be adopted only on the basis of a proposal from the Commission, unless otherwise provided for in the Treaties'. This means that the Commission has the exclusive right to initiate the legislative procedure, even though the Council is a 'actual catalyst for many legislative initiatives'. Parliament may also formally ask the Commission to submit a legislative proposal, but the Commission may reject such a proposal with its reasons. The President of the Commission (now the former Prime Minister of Luxembourg, Jean-Claude Juncker) draws up the agenda for EU work. Decisions will be taken by simple majority vote, usually by a "written procedure" by circumventing proposals and adopting them if no objection is expressed.[A quote is necessary] Because Ireland refused to agree to the changes made to the Treaty of Lisbon in 2007, for each of the 28 Member States, including the President and the High Representative for Foreign and Security Policy (now Federica Mogherini). Member States negotiate too intensively with the Commissioners (and above all with the portfolios they hold). As a group, the members of the Commission will then have a qualified majority in the Council for Parliament's approval and a majority in Parliament for Parliament's approval. The proposal to take Commissioners from an elected Parliament has not been adopted in the Treaty of Lisbon. This means that the Commissioners, through the appointment process, are under the unselected authority of the governments of the Member States.

paragraphs.context: Members of the Commission have different privileges, such as exemption from taxes (but not from EU taxes) and immunity from official acts. Members of the Commission have sometimes been found to have misused their office, especially since Parliament passed a motion of censure on the Santer Commission in 1999 and finally resigned on the charge of corruption. This led to one main case, the Commission v Edith Cresson, in which the Court of Justice of the European Communities held that the Commissioner, who entrusted him with the function of dentist, for which he was clearly incompetent, did not in fact violate any law. Unlike the gentle approach taken by the European Court of Justice, the Committee of Experts stated that culture had evolved in such a way that few Commissioners had 'a low sense of responsibility'. This led to the establishment of a European Anti-Fraud Office. In 2012, it investigated the Maltese Health Commissioner, John Dalli, who resigned quickly after claiming to have received a EUR 60 million bribe under the Tobacco Products Directive. In addition to the Commission, the European Central Bank has a relative autonomy in the conduct of monetary policy for the management of the euro. It has a board of six appointed by the European Council on a recommendation from the Council. The President of the Council and the Member of the Commission may attend the meetings of the ECB but shall not have the right to vote.

paragraphs.context: Although the Commission has the exclusive right to take legislative initiatives, the European Parliament and the Council of the European Union have the power to make changes and veto during the legislative process. According to Articles 9 and 10 of the Treaty on European Union, the EU follows the "principle of equality of its citizens" and is intended to be based on "representative democracy". In practice, equality and democracy are inadequate, because elected representatives of Parliament cannot legislate against the will of the Commission, the citizens of the smaller countries have ten times the power to vote in Parliament as citizens of the largest countries, and the legislation requires a 'quantity majority' or unanimity in the Council. As a justification for this 'democratic deficit' under the Treaties, it is generally considered that the full integration of the European economy and political institutions requires technical coordination of experts, while the people's perception of the EU has developed and nationalistic feelings have decreased since the war. Over time, this has meant that Parliament has gradually adopted more votes: it has been an unelected Assembly, its first direct elections in 1979, and it has gained more and more rights in the legislative process. The rights of citizens are therefore limited in comparison with the democratic policies of all EU Member States: Article 11 TEU states that citizens and associations have rights, such as their making their views public, and they present an initiative that the Commission must consider with a million signatures. Article 227 TFEU provides for a new right for citizens to petition Parliament in matters relating to them. Parliamentary elections shall take place every five years and the votes of the Members of the European Parliament shall be held in the Member States by means of a proportional representation or one transferable vote. There are 750 Members of the European Parliament and their number is 'less comparable' according to the size of the Member State. This means that, although the Council is to be a body representing the Member States, citizens of smaller Member States will have more votes in Parliament than citizens of larger Member States. Members of the European Parliament are divided, as they do in national parliaments, in party politics: the conservative European People's Party is currently the largest, and the European Social Democratic Party is leading the opposition. The parties do not receive public funds from the EU, as the Court of Justice stated in the Parti écologise "Les Verts" v Parliament, that this was a matter entirely regulated by the Member States. Parliament's powers include investigating maladministration or appointing an ombudsman to wait for trial. It may require the Commission to answer questions and, by a two-thirds majority, it may put a motion of censure to the Commission as a whole (as it did the Santer Commission in 1999). In some cases, Parliament has clear rights of consultation, which the Commission really must respect. However, its role in the legislative process is still limited because no Member can, in fact, adopt legislation without the Commission and the Council, which means that power ("cracy") is not in the hands of the direct elected representatives of the people ("dems"): it is not yet true in the EU that "government is in the hands of many or few".

paragraphs.context: The second main legislative body is the Council, composed of the various ministers of the Member States. The Heads of Government of the Member States will also convene a European Council (a separate body) which is defined in Article 15 TEU as "a necessary impetus for its development and defining general political guidelines and priorities". It meets every six months, and its President (now former Polish Prime Minister Donald Tusk) is meant to 'promote his work', but not'regulatory tasks' itself. The Council does this: in fact, it is the governments of the Member States, but each meeting has a different minister depending on the subject being discussed (e.g. environmental issues, participation and vote by the environment ministers of the Member States, foreign affairs, foreign ministers, etc.). The Minister must have the power to represent and disband the Member States in their decisions. When voting takes place, it is weighted in reverse to the size of the Member States, so the larger Member States do not control the smaller Member States. The total number of votes is 352, but most legislative acts must have qualified majority voting, if not unanimity. According to Article 16(4) TEU and Article 238(3) TFEU, this represents at least 55 % of the Council's members (no votes) representing 65 % of the EU population: currently around 74% or 260 % of the 352 votes. This is crucial during the legislative process.

paragraphs.context: To develop new legislation, Article 294 TFEU defines the "normal legislative procedure" applicable to most EU acts. Basically, there are three readings starting with the Commission proposal, in which Parliament must vote by a majority of all Members (not just those present) in order to prevent or propose amendments, and the Council must vote by a qualified majority in order to approve the amendments, but unanimously in order to prevent the Commission's amendment. If there is no agreement between the various institutions, a "committal committee" representing the Members of the European Parliament, the Ministers and the Commission shall be convened in order to reach agreement on a joint text: if this works, it shall be sent back to Parliament and the Council for approval by an absolute and qualified majority. This means that a majority in Parliament, a minority in the Council and a majority in the Commission can prevent legislative changes: EU legislation is more difficult to change than to remain unchanged. There is a different procedure in the budget. The Council shall authorise closer cooperation between at least the sub-groups of the Member States. The Commission should inform the governments of the Member States immediately before the beginning of the legislative procedure. The EU as a whole can only operate within the framework of its powers laid down in the Treaties. Articles 4 and 5 of the TEU state that competence remains with the Member States if they have not been given, even though the question of Kompetenz-Kompetenz is being discussed: who ultimately has the "power" to define the EU's "powers". Many courts in the Member States believe that they are making a decision, while other parliaments in the Member States believe that they are making a decision, while within the EU the Court considers that it has a final say.

paragraphs.context: The EU legal area has played an important role in the development of EU legislation, as it has taken on the task of interpreting the Treaties and speeding up economic and political integration. Today, the Court of Justice of the European Union is the most important court with a higher court of the European Communities (generally abbreviated to the Court of Justice) dealing with cases of greater public interest and a general court dealing with detailed but not generally important issues. In addition, there is the Civil Service Tribunal, which deals with EU staff issues, followed by a separate Court of Auditors. pursuant to Article 19(2) of the Treaty on European Union There is one judge from each Member State, currently 28, who has the "qualifications required for the appointment of the largest judicial offices" (or the General Court of the Union "the possibility of appointing a High Court of Justice"). The judges will elect the president for three years. According to Article 19(3) TEU, questions relating to EU law will ultimately be interpreted before a court. In fact, the majority of EU legislation is applicable to the courts of the Member States (England Court of Appeal, German Bundesgerichtshof, Belgian Cour du travail, etc.). they may, however, ask questions to the EU Court of Justice for a preliminary ruling. The role of the Court of Justice is 'to ensure that the interpretation and application of the Treaties are governed by law', although realistically it is able to extend and develop the law in accordance with the principles it considers appropriate. It is claimed that this has been done through both seminal and controversial judgments, including Van Gend en Loos, Mangold v Helm and Kadi v Commission.

paragraphs.context: Since its establishment, the EU has been working in the midst of increasing diversity of national and global justice systems. This has led both the Court of Justice of the European Communities and the highest national courts to develop principles for resolving conflicts of laws between different systems. Within the Union, the Court of Justice considers that where EU law is incompatible with national law, EU law is a priority. In the first significant case in 1964, Costa v ENEL, a Milanese lawyer, and Costa, a former shareholder of the energy company, refused to pay their electricity bill to Enel as a protest against the nationalisation of Italian energy companies. He claimed that the Italian nationalisation law was incompatible with the Treaty of Rome and requested that it be referred to both the Italian Constitutional Court and Article 267 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. The Italian Constitutional Court held that, since the Law on Nationalisation was from 1962 and the Convention was in force from 1958, Costa had no requirements. Instead, the Court held that, ultimately, the Treaty of Rome did not in any way prevent the nationalisation of energy and, in any event, according to the provisions of the Treaty, only the Commission could have made a claim, not Costa. However, Costa was in principle entitled to plead that the agreement was incompatible with national law and the Court should take into account his claim to lodge an appeal if its decision is not contested. The Court reiterated its view at Van Gend en Loos and stated that the Member States 'although in limited areas they have limited their sovereign rights and created a set of laws applicable both to their citizens and to themselves' on the basis of reciprocity. EU legislation "would not be exceeded by national provisions, even if they were formulated... without calling into question the Community legal basis". This meant that the Member State's 'following unilateral action' was not in force. Similarly, Amministrazione delle Finanze v Simmenthal SpA claimed in Amministrazione delle Finanze v Simmenthal SpA that the public health inspection fee for imports of beef from France to Italy under the Italian Law of 1970 was contrary to two regulations for the years 1964 and 1968. In accordance with the principle of primacy of Community law, the Court stated that 'the measures directly applicable to the institutions (such as the relevant regulations) 'do not automatically apply the provisions of existing national law'. This was necessary in order to prevent Member States from "refusaling unconditionally and irrevocably" the obligations of the Treaty which could "infringe" the foundations of the EU. However, despite the views of the Court of Justice, the same analysis has not been accepted by the national courts of the Member States.

paragraphs.context: Although all Member States generally recognise that EU legislation is a priority over national legislation if it is agreed in the Treaties, they do not accept that the Court of Justice has the last say on constitutional issues affecting democracy and human rights. In the United Kingdom, the basic principle is that Parliament, as a sovereign expression of democratic legitimacy, can decide whether it wishes to explicitly regulate against EU law. However, this would only happen if citizens clearly wanted to leave the EU. In Case R (Factortame Ltd) the Minister for Transport stated that 'any limitation of Parliament's sovereignty, whatever it accepted in adopting the 1972 European Community law, was entirely voluntary' and therefore 'it has always been clear' that the UK courts are obliged 'to go beyond all national legal rules which have been found to be incompatible with the rules directly implemented by Community law'. Recently the Supreme Court of the United Kingdom stated that although the UK Constitution has not been codified, the letter ‘HS2 Action Alliance Ltd’ states that the fundamental principles of common law may exist and that Parliament ‘has not considered or allowed the repeal of these principles’ in its 1972 law of the European Communities. The German Constitutional Court’s view of Solange I and Solange II’s decisions is that if the EU does not respect its constitutional fundamental rights and principles (in particular democracy, the rule of law and the principles of a social state) it cannot go beyond German law. However, according to the nicknames of the judgments, the EU 'as long as' is trying to democratise its institutions and has a framework that protects fundamental human rights, it would not review EU law in order to be compatible with German constitutional principles. Most other Member States have made similar reservations. This suggests that the legitimacy of the EU is based on the ultimate authority of the Member States, its real commitment to human rights and the democratic will of the people.

paragraphs.context: Although constitutional legislation concerns the administrative structure of the European Union, the administrative law obliges the EU institutions and Member States to comply with the law. Both Member States and the Commission have a general legal right or a right (locus stand) to bring actions against EU institutions and other Member States for breach of the Treaties. On the basis of the EU, the Court also held that the Treaties allowed citizens or companies to bring actions against the institutions of the EU and the Member States for breach of the Treaties and regulations if they were correctly interpreted in order to create rights and obligations. However, the directives stated in 1986 that citizens or businesses should not raise claims against non-state parties. This meant that the courts of the Member States were not obliged to apply an EU law in which a national rule would be incompatible, even if the government of a Member State could be sued if it imposed an obligation on another citizen or company. These "direct effect" rules limit the extent to which EU law is to be governed by national courts. All the activities of the EU institutions can be reviewed and evaluated in accordance with the principles of proportionality, particularly in the case of general principles of law or fundamental rights. As a means of redress for an applicant who is in breach of the law, there is often financial damage, but the court may also claim a particular performance or give an interim judgment in order to ensure that the law is as effective as possible.

paragraphs.context: Although the Treaties and regulations have a direct impact (if clear, unconditional and immediate), directives generally do not give citizens (as opposed to a Member State) the right to sue other citizens. In theory, this is because Article 288 TFEU states that the directives are addressed to the Member States and that they generally "leave the national authorities to choose the form and methods" for implementation. This partly reflects the fact that directives often create minimum standards, allowing Member States to apply stricter standards. For example, the Working Time Directive requires each worker to have at least four weeks of paid leave per year, but most Member States require more than 28 days of national legislation. However, the current position of the Court of Justice allows citizens to make demands based on national legislation implementing directives but not on the directives themselves. Directives do not have a direct effect (i.e. "horizontal" effect) (i.e. between non-governmental parties). This view was immediately controversial and, at the beginning of the 1990s, three Advocates-General convincingly argued that directives should create rights and obligations for all citizens. The Court refused, but there are five major exceptions.

paragraphs.context: Firstly, if the deadline for implementing the directive is not respected, the Member State cannot implement conflicting laws and the citizen can rely on the directive in such an action (so-called "vertical" direct effect). Pubblico Ministero v Ratti, because the Italian Government had not implemented Directive 73/173/EEC on packaging and packaging solvents by the deadline, it no longer implemented the 1963 illegal national law against Ratt’s solvent and varnish business. A Member State cannot 'apply to individuals in the manner in which it has failed to fulfil its obligations under the Directive'. Secondly, a citizen or an undertaking may rely on the Directive, not only in a dispute with a public authority, but in a dispute with another citizen or company. Accordingly, in its judgment in CIA Security v. Signalson and Securitel, the Court held that a company called CIA Security could defend itself against competitors’ claims that it had failed to comply with the Belgian regulation on alert systems since 1991 because it had not been notified to the Commission as required by the Directive. Thirdly, if the directive reflects the 'general principle' of EU law, it can be invoked between private non-governmental parties before the deadline for its implementation. This is the result of the judgment of Kücükdeveci v Swedennx GmbH & Co KG, in which Article 622 of the German Civil Code states that the working years of persons under the age of 25 are not counted against the increasing legal dismissal before dismissal. Kücükdeveci worked for Swedennx GmbH & Co KG for 10 years at the age of 18-28 before his dismissal. He claimed that a law that is not counted under 25 is illegal age discrimination under the framework directive on equal opportunities in working life. The Court considered that he could rely on the Directive because equality is also a general principle of EU law. Thirdly, if the defendant is a State ambassador, even if it is not a central government, it can still be bound by directives. In Foster v British Gas plc, the Court held that Foster was entitled to bring an action for discrimination on grounds of sex against his employer British Gas plc, who retired women at the age of 60 and men at the age of 65 if 1) under a State measure, 2) Foster provided a public service and 3) had special powers. This may also be true if the company is privatised, since it was held in a water company which was responsible for basic water supply.

paragraphs.context: Fourthly, national courts are obliged to interpret national legislation "where possible according to the wording and purpose of the Directive". The textbooks (although not the court itself) are often referred to as "indirect effect". The Court held at the Marleasing SA v La Comercial SA that the Spanish Court had to interpret the provisions of the general civil law relating to contracts which do not have cause or have cheated creditors in accordance with Article 11 of the First Company Law Directive, since they require that they be incorporated, null and void only for a certain reason. The Court quickly acknowledged that the obligation to interpret could not conflict with the clear words of the national statute. Fifthly, if a Member State has not implemented the directive, the citizen may not necessarily bring an action against non-state parties but may bring an action against the Member State itself for failure to implement the law. The Italian Government had therefore not set up an insurance fund against Italy in Francovich, which would require unpaid wages from employees if their employers had been insolvent, as required by the Insolvency Protection Directive. As a result, Francovich, a former employee of a company in Venetian bankruptcy, was able to claim from the Italian Government ITL 6 million in compensation for its loss. The Court held that if the Directive confers rights on individuals and if there is a causal link between the infringement of the EU and the loss of the applicant, damages must be paid. The fact that incompatible law is the law of Parliament is no excuse.

paragraphs.context: The principles of European Union law are the legal rules developed by the Court of Justice of the European Communities, which are unwritten rules which are not specifically laid down in the Treaties but which affect the way in which European Union law is interpreted and applied. In drawing up these principles, the courts have made use of a number of different sources, such as international public law and legal doctrine and principles in the legal systems of the Member States of the European Union and in the case law of the European Court of Human Rights. The general principles adopted in European Union law include fundamental rights (see human rights), proportionality, legal certainty, equality before the law and subsidiarity.

paragraphs.context: The European Court of Justice has recognised the principle of proportionality as one of the general principles of European Union law since the 1950s. According to the general principle of proportionality, the legality of the action depends on whether it was appropriate and necessary to achieve the objectives pursued. Where several appropriate measures have to be chosen, the least burdensome measures must be introduced and the damage they cause must not be disproportionate to the objectives pursued. The principle of proportionality is also recognised in Article 5 of the EC Treaty, which states that 'Community action must not go beyond what is necessary to achieve the objectives of this Treaty'.

paragraphs.context: The concept of legal certainty has been recognised as one of the general principles of European Union law before the Court of Justice since the 1960s. It is an important general principle of international law and public law, which has preceded European Union law. As a general principle of European Union law, it means that the law must be sure because it is clear and precise and its legal effects are foreseeable, especially when applied to economic obligations. In the European Union, laws that have legal effects must have an appropriate legal basis. The legislation of the Member States implementing European Union law must be formulated in such a way that it is clearly understood by those who are subject to it. The general principle of legal certainty prohibits legislative acts in European Union law, i.e. laws should not enter into force before they are published. The doctrine of trust built on the principles of legal certainty and good faith is also a central part of the principle of general legal certainty in European Union law. According to the doctrine of legitimate expectations, this is the case and that 'those who act in good faith on the basis of the law as it is or seems to be should not be frustrated in their expectations'.

paragraphs.context: The original Treaties on the European Union do not mention the protection of fundamental rights. The actions of the European Union, namely the legislative and administrative actions of the European Union institutions, were not intended to fall within the scope of human rights. The only concern at that time was that Member States should be prevented from violating human rights, which is why the European Convention on Human Rights was established in 1950 and the European Court of Human Rights was established. The European Court of Justice has recognised fundamental rights as a general principle of European Union law because the need to ensure that European Union measures are in line with the human rights enshrined in the constitution of the Member States became increasingly evident. In 1999, the European Council set up a body to draw up a European Convention on Human Rights, which could form the constitutional basis of the European Union and be tailored, in particular, to the European Union and its institutions. The Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union lists fundamental rights under the European Convention on Human Rights, the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Parliament of 1989 and the Treaties establishing the European Union.

paragraphs.context: The 2007 Treaty of Lisbon explicitly recognised fundamental rights by providing in Article 6(1) that "the Union recognises the rights, freedoms and principles set out in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union of 7 December 2000 as adopted in Strasbourg on 12 December 2007 and having the same legal value as the Treaties". Consequently, the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union has become an integral part of the law of the European Union, codifying the fundamental rights previously regarded as general principles of European Union law. In fact, after the Treaty of Lisbon, the Charter of Fundamental Rights and the Convention are now in force at the same time in accordance with European Union law, even though the European Court of Justice has implemented the latter with regard to European Union measures and the European Court of Human Rights with regard to national measures.

paragraphs.context: The chapter on social policy is a chapter of the 1997 Treaty of Amsterdam dealing with social policy issues in European Union legislation. In 1989, representatives of the social partners (UNICE), the employers' association, the European Trade Union Confederation (ETUC) and the European Centre of Public Enterprises (CEEP) developed the basis for the social chapter. At the European Council in Strasbourg in 1989, a relaxed version was adopted as a social charter. The Social Charter sets out 30 general principles, such as health and safety at work, the rights of people with disabilities and the elderly, workers' rights, vocational training and improving living conditions. The Social Charter formed the basis for European Community legislation on these issues by 40 acts.

The UK then adopted the Social Policy Agreement, the 1994 Works Council Directive, which required consultation of employees in companies, and the 1996 Parental Leave Directive. During the ten years following the Treaty of Amsterdam and following the adoption of the chapter on social policy, the European Union has taken political initiatives in various areas of social policy, including labour market and industrial relations, equal opportunities, health and safety, public health, the protection of children, the disabled and the elderly, poverty, migrant workers, education and youth.

paragraphs.context: EU competition law is based on the European Coal and Steel Community (ECSC) agreement between France, Italy, Belgium, the Netherlands, Luxembourg and Germany in 1951 after World War II. The purpose of the agreement was to prevent Germany from regaining its power in coal and steel production because its members felt that its power had contributed to the outbreak of war. Article 65 of the Agreement prohibited cartels and Article 66 provided for concentration or mergers and for the abuse of a dominant position by undertakings. This was the first time that the principles of competition law were incorporated into a multilateral regional agreement and introduced a European model of competition law. In 1957, competition rules were incorporated into the Treaty of Rome, also known as the EC Treaty, which established the European Economic Community (EEC). The Treaty of Rome confirmed the adoption of competition law as one of the main objectives of the EEC "by providing a system to ensure that competition in the common market is not distorted". The two main provisions of EU competition law on companies were laid down in Article 85, which prohibited anti-competitive agreements with certain exceptions, and Article 86, which prohibits the abuse of a dominant position. The agreement also laid down the principles of competition law in the Member States, Article 90 of which concerns public undertakings, and Article 92 on State aid. The merger regulations were not included because the Member States were unable to reach an agreement at the time.

answers.text: France, Italy, Belgium, the Netherlands, Luxembourg and Germany

paragraphs.context: The Treaty of Lisbon today prohibits the restrictive agreements in Article 101(1), including price fixing. Article 101(2) provides that such agreements are automatically null and void. Article 101(3) provides for exceptions where a conspiracy is intended for distribution or technological innovation, provides consumers with a "fair share" of the benefits and does not contain unreasonable restrictions that threaten to eliminate competition anywhere (or which comply with the general principle of proportionality of the European Union). Article 102 prohibits abuse of a dominant position, such as price discrimination and exclusive trade. Article 102 of the Treaty allows the European Council to regulate mergers between undertakings (now Regulation 139/2004/EC). The general criterion is whether an EC-wide concentration (merger or acquisition) (i.e. impact on several EU Member States) can significantly impede effective competition. Articles 106 and 107 of the Treaty provide that the right of a Member State to provide public services must not be prevented, but otherwise public undertakings must comply with the same principles of competition as undertakings. Article 107 of the Treaty provides for a general rule that the State is not to receive aid or aid from private parties in the event of distortion of free competition and provides for exceptions to charitable organisations, regional development objectives and in the event of a natural disaster.

paragraphs.context: Although the concept of "social market economy" was not incorporated into EU law until 2007, free movement and trade were at the heart of Europe's development since the Treaty of Rome in 1957. According to the standard theory of the comparative advantage, two countries can both benefit from trade even if one of them has a less profitable economy in all respects. Like other regional organisations, such as the North American Free Trade Association or the World Trade Organisation, the dismantling of trade barriers and the free movement of goods, services, labour and capital, consumer prices are to be reduced. It was originally a theory that the free trade area tends to give way to a customs union which led to a common market, then to monetary union, then to a monetary and fiscal union, a political union, and ultimately to a full federation typical of a federal state. In Europe, however, these stages were very confusing and it is not clear whether the 'end game' should be the same as a country that has traditionally been understood. In practice, free trade without standards in order to ensure fair trade may benefit some people and groups in countries (particularly large companies) far more than others, but it puts a strain on people who do not have bargaining power in growing markets, particularly workers, consumers, small businesses, emerging industries and communities. Articles 28 to 37 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union establish the principle of the free movement of goods within the EU, while Articles 45 to 66 require the free movement of persons, services and capital. These so-called four freedoms were thought to prevent physical barriers (e.g. customs), technical barriers (e.g. different laws on safety, consumer or environmental standards) and tax obstacles (e.g. different VAT rates). The tension of the law is that free movement and trade are not intended to flow into a licence that justifies unlimited commercial profit. The Treaties restrict free trade and give priority to other values, such as public health, consumer protection, workers' rights, fair competition and the improvement of the environment. The Court of Justice has increasingly held that the general objectives of the Treaty in support of the specific objectives of free trade are to improve people's well-being.

paragraphs.context: Often the rules apply neutrally to all products, but they may have a greater practical impact on imports than domestic products. For such a 'indirect' discriminatory (or 'clearly applicable' act, the Court has developed more arguments: either for requirements under Article 36 or for supplementary 'compulsory' or 'overriding' requirements, such as consumer protection, improving labour standards, protecting the environment, diversity of the press, fairness in trade, and more: classes are not closed. In the most famous case, Rewe-Zentral AG v Bundesmonopol für Brantwein, the Court ruled that the German law requiring all alcoholic beverages and liqueurs (not only imported) to have an alcoholic strength of at least 25 % is contrary to Article 34 of the TFEU because it has a greater negative impact on imports. German liqueurs were more than 25 % alcohol, but Cassis de Dijon, which Rewe-Zentrale AG wanted to import from France, was only 15-20 % alcohol. The Court rejected the arguments of the German Government that the measure would be proportionate to protect public health under Article 36 TFEU, since stronger drinks were available and sufficient labelling would be sufficient for consumers to understand what they were buying. This rule applies primarily to the requirements relating to the content or packaging of the product. In Walter Rau Lebensmittelwerke v De Smedt PVBA, the Court ruled that the Belgian law requiring all margarines to be in cubic packages infringed Article 34 and was not justified by the pursuit of consumer protection. The argument that Belgians believe that it is butter if it is not shaped into cubes was disproportionate: it would 'extremely exceed the requirements of the subject' and labelling would protect consumers 'as effectively'. In 2003, the Commission v Italy required Italian legislation that cocoa products containing other vegetable fats should not be labelled as ‘success products’. It must have been "chocolate." All Italian chocolate was made from cocoa butter only, but British, Danish and Irish manufacturers used other vegetable fats. They claimed that the law violated Article 34. The Court held that the low level of vegetable fat does not justify chocolate substitute labelling. This was demeaning in the eyes of consumers. "A neutral and objective statement was enough to protect consumers. Where Member States impose significant barriers to the use of a product, they may also infringe Article 34. In its 2009 case, the Court of Justice held, in the Commission v Italy, that the Italian law prohibiting motorcycles or mopeds from towing trailers infringed Article 34. The law was again applied impartially to everyone, but it had a disproportionate impact on importers because Italian companies did not produce trailers. This was not a product requirement, but the Court concluded that a ban would prevent people from buying it: it would have 'a significant impact on consumer behaviour', which would 'have an impact on the market access of the product concerned'. It would require justification under Article 36 or as a mandatory requirement.

paragraphs.context: Unlike product requirements or other laws prohibiting access to the market, the Court developed the presumption that "sales arrangements" should not fall within Article 34 TFEU if they are applied equally to all sellers and affect them in the same way. In Keck and Mithouard, two importers claimed that under the French competition law their charges, which prevented them from selling Pico beer at wholesale prices, were unlawful. The objective of the law was to prevent the throat surgery competition, not to prevent trade. The Court held that 'under the law and in fact' it was an equally appropriate'sales arrangement' (not an arrangement which alters the content of a product) which was not covered by Article 34 and therefore did not have to be justified. Sales arrangements can be considered to have an unequal effect in the case of 'in fact', particularly when traders in another Member State attempt to break into the market, but there are restrictions on advertising and marketing. In the case of Konsumentombudsmannen v De Agostini, the Court examined the Swedish prohibitions on advertising to children under 12 years of age and misleading advertisements on skin care products. Although the prohibitions have remained (as a legitimate or mandatory requirement under Article 36), the Court stressed that full marketing bans may be disproportionate if advertising is "the only effective form of promotion enabling [the trader] to enter the market". In the case of Konsumentombudsmannen v Gourmet AB, the Court ruled that the advertising of alcohol on radio, television and magazines could be prohibited in full in Article 34, where advertising was the only way for sellers to gain the "traditional social practices and local customs and customs" of consumers, but the national courts again decide whether it is justified under Article 36 in order to protect public health. According to the Unfair Commercial Practices Directive, the EU has harmonised restrictions on marketing and advertising in order to prohibit behaviour which distorts the behaviour of average consumers is misleading or aggressive and to list examples that are considered unfair. States increasingly need to mutually recognise each other's regulatory standards, while the EU has sought to harmonise the minimum ideals of best practice. It is hoped that standards will be raised in order to avoid "beginning at the bottom" of regulation and to allow consumers to obtain products from across the continent.

paragraphs.context: Since its foundation, the Treaties have sought to enable people to achieve their goals of life in any country by means of free movement. Due to the economic nature of the project, the European Community initially focused on the free movement of workers as a "production factor". Since the 1970s, however, the focus has shifted to the development of a more "social" Europe. Freedom of movement was increasingly based on 'citizenship', so people had the right to give them the opportunity to become economically and socially active instead of being a prerequisite for economic activity. This means that the fundamental rights of the "worker" of Article 45 TFEU are a specific expression of the general rights of citizens in Articles 18 to 21 TFEU. According to the Court of Justice, 'worker' is anyone who is economically active, including all those who are employed, under the guidance of another person, 'for compensation'. However, you do not have to pay for work in cash if you are protected as an employee. For example, in Steymann v Staatsexpertaris van Justitie, a German man claimed the right of residence in the Netherlands when he volunteered for the plumbing and domestic work of the Bhagwan Community, which provided for the material needs of all, regardless of their contribution. The Court held that Mr Steymann had the right to remain, provided that at least an 'indirect countermeasure' was obtained for the work he had done. The status of "employer" means protection against all forms of discrimination by the government and employers in access to employment, taxation and social security rights. On the other hand, a citizen who is "all citizens of a Member State" (Article 20(1) TFEU) has the right to seek employment, to vote in municipal elections and in elections to the European Parliament, but a more limited right to claim social security. In practice, freedom of movement has become politically controversial when nationalistic political parties have manipulated fears that immigrants are taking people's jobs and benefits (paradoxically at the same time). Nevertheless, in practice "all available studies show that labour mobility has little impact on the salaries and employment of local workers".

qas.question: Which entity focused upon the free movement of workers?

paragraphs.context: Articles 1 to 7 on the free movement of workers set out the main provisions on equal treatment of workers. Firstly, Articles 1 to 4 generally require workers to be able to enter into employment, to enter into contracts and not to be discriminated against against against nationals of a Member State. In a famous case, the Belgian Football Association v. Bosman, Belgian footballer Jean-Marc Bosman, argued that he should be able to move from R.F.C. de Liège to USL Dunkerque at the end of the contract, regardless of whether Dunkerque could afford to pay Liège the normal transfer fees. The Court held that 'transfer rules constitute an obstacle to free movement' and that they are unlawful unless they can be justified in the public interest, but this is unlikely. In Groener v Minister of Education, the Court accepted that the requirement to teach Gaelics at the Dublin Model School could be justified as part of a general practice promoting Irish but only if the measure is not disproportionate. On the other hand, Angonese v. Cassa di Risparmio di Bolzano SpA, the Italian bank in Bolzano, was not allowed to claim from Angones a bilingual certificate available only from Bolzano. With its "horizontal" direct effect on Article 45 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU), the Court justified that people from other countries would have little chance of obtaining a certificate and that "it is impossible to provide evidence of the required language skills in any other way", the measure was disproportionate. Secondly, Article 7(2) requires equal treatment in taxation. In the Finanzamt Köln Altstadt v Schumacker judgment, the Court held that it was contrary to Article 45 TFEU to deny tax advantages (e.g. married couples and social security allowances) to a man who worked in Germany who lived in Belgium when other Germans received benefits. By contrast, in Weigel v Finanzlandesdirektion für Vorarlberg, the Court rejected Weigel’s claim that the re-registration charge on his car brought into Austria infringed his right of free movement. Although the tax had a 'probable negative impact on migrant workers's decision to exercise their right to free movement' since the levy applied equally to Austrians because there was no EU legislation on this issue, it had to be considered justified. Thirdly, people must be treated equally with regard to'social interests', even though the conditions of residence have been approved by the Court of Justice. In his judgment in Hendrix v Workers' Insurance Institution, the Court held that the Dutch national was not entitled to continue invalidity benefits when he moved to Belgium because the benefit was 'closely linked to the Dutch socio-economic situation'. On the other hand, in Geven v Land Nordrhein-Westfalen, the Court held that a Dutch woman living in the Netherlands who works in Germany between 3 and 14 hours a week is not entitled to German child supplements, even if the wife of a man who worked full-time in Germany but lived in Austria could have. The general justification for restricting freedom of movement in Article 45(3) TFEU is 'public order, public security or public health', and Article 45(4) also contains a general exception to 'employment in public services'.

qas.question: In the case Geven v Land Nordrhein-Westfalen, how many hours was the Dutch woman in question working in Germany?

paragraphs.context: The Court of Justice has increasingly regarded EU citizenship as a 'basic status' for nationals of Member States and has therefore increased the number of social services that people can use wherever they move. The Court of Justice has required higher education and other forms of vocational education and training to be better available, albeit with application periods. In its judgment in Commission v Austria, the Court held that Austria was not entitled to restrict seats in Austrian universities to Austrian students in order to avoid'structural, human and financial problems' if foreign students (mainly Germans) sought seats because there was little evidence of the real problem.

paragraphs.context: Not only does the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union create rights for "workers" who do not normally have the power to negotiate on the market, but it also protects the "freedom of establishment" of Article 49 and the "freedom to provide services" of Article 56. In Gebhard v Consiglio dellórdine degli Avvocati e Procuratori di Milano, the Court held that "stability and continuity" means "stability and continuity" in economic life, whereas "services" meant "temporary" activity. This meant that Mr Stuttgart's lawyer, who had established a Chamber in Milan and had been condemned by the Milan Bar Council for not registering, had the right to claim freedom of establishment or freedom of service. However, requirements which must be registered in Milan before they can carry out their activities shall be allowed if they are not discriminatory, justified by "overriding requirements of the general interest" and applied proportionately. Any person or entity engaged in an economic activity, in particular self-employed persons or "enterprises", such as undertakings or undertakings, has the right to set up a business without unjustified restrictions. The Court held that both the government of a Member State and the private party could prevent the freedom of establishment, so Article 49 had both a vertical and a horizontal direct effect. In Reyners v Belgium, the Court held that it was unjustified to refuse to include a lawyer in a Belgian bar because he lacked Belgian nationality. Article 49 TFEU states that States are exempt from the infringement of the freedom of establishment of others when they exercise "official authority", but this was not the work of a lawyer (as opposed to the work of a court). By contrast, in the Commission v Italy, the Court held that the requirement for lawyers in Italy to comply with the maximum tariffs, unless an agreement has been concluded with the customer, is not a restriction. The Grand Chamber of the Court held that the Commission had not demonstrated that this had a purpose or an effect which would restrict the access of professionals to the market. Therefore, there was no prima facie breach of the freedom of establishment which should have been justified.

answers.text: the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union

the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union

paragraphs.context: In 2006, toxic waste was spilled on the coast of Côte d'Ivoire from a European vessel and the Commission therefore examined the legislation on toxic waste. Environment Commissioner Stavros Dimas said that 'this very toxic waste should never have left the European Union'. Franco Frattini, Commissioner for Justice, Freedom and Security, and Mr Dimas, proposed criminal convictions for "ecological crimes". The powers of the Union were challenged by the Court of Justice in 2005, which led to a victory for the Commission. This decision is a precedent for the Commission to be able, on a supranational basis, to legislate on criminal law – something that has never been done before. So far, the only other proposal has been the proposal for a directive on intellectual property rights. The European Parliament put forward proposals against this legislation on the grounds that criminal law should not fall within the competence of the EU but was rejected in the vote. However, in October 2007, the Court of Justice concluded that the Commission cannot propose criminal sanctions, only that they must exist.

paragraphs.context: Amazon rainforest (Portugal: Floresta Amazônica or Amazônia; Spanish: Selva Amazónica, Amazonía or Amazonia in general); French: Forêt amazonienne; Dutch: Amazonegenwoud), also known in English as Amazonia or Amazon jungle, is a damp leaf forest covering most of the Amazon South American basin. The floor area is 7 million square kilometres (2 700 000 square kilometres), of which the rainforest covers 5 500 000 square kilometres (2 100 000 square kilometres). There are nine nations in the region. Most of the forest is in Brazil, 60% of the rainforest, Peru 13%, Colombia 10% and small quantities in Venezuela, Ecuador, Bolivia, Guyana, Surinam and French Guiana. In the states or departments of the four nations they call themselves "Amazonas". Amazon represents more than half of the world’s remaining rain forests and is the world’s largest and biodiverse tropical rain forests with an estimated 390 billion individual trees divided into 16 000 species.

paragraphs.context: Since the Chalk-Paleogene extinction event, the extinction and rainy climate of the dinosaurs may have allowed the tropical rain forest to spread to the mainland. 66–34 Myasta rainforest reached up to 45 degrees south. Over the last 34 million years, climate changes have allowed the Savanna regions to expand into the tropics. For example, during Oligocene the rain forest reached a relatively narrow strip. It expanded again in the middle of Miocene, after which it withdrew mostly to the interior formation on the last glacier. However, the rain forest was still successful during these ice ages, which enabled the preservation and development of a wide variety of species.

paragraphs.context: There is evidence that there have been significant changes in the vegetation of Amazon rain forests over the past 21 000 years through LGM and subsequent gladiament. Analysis of sediment deposits from Amazon basin paleolaks and Amazon Fan shows that the rainfall in the basin was lower during LGM than at present, and this was almost certainly related to the reduction of wet tropical vegetation in the basin. However, there is a debate on the extent of the reduction. Some researchers claim that the rain forest has been reduced to a small, isolated refugia separated by open forest and grass. Other researchers claim that the rain forest has remained largely intact, but has less spread to the north, south, and east. This discussion has proved difficult to resolve because the practical limitations of working in the rain forest lead to a biased data sampling from the center of the Amazon basin and both explanations receive a reasonable amount of support from the available information.

paragraphs.context: The relationship between the ctenophores and the rest of Metazoa is very important for us to understand the origin of the early development of animals and the origin of multicellularity. It has been the focus of the debate for many years. The Ktenophors are supposed to be a sister family for Bilter, Cnidaria’s sister, Cnidaria’s sister, Placozo’s and Bilter’s sister, as well as all other animal seals. Several studies on the presence and absence of gene family members and signs (e.g. homeoboxes, core receptors, Wnt signal route and sodium channels) found that ctenophores are either sisters of Cnidaria, Placozo and Bilter or sisters of all other animal phyla. Several more recent studies comparing a complete sequence of ctenophores with other sequenced animal genomes have also supported ctenophores as a sister generation for all other animals. This position indicates that the types of nerve and muscle cells either disappeared in large animal lines (e.g. Porifera) or developed independently in the ctenofore line. Other researchers have argued, however, that placing Ctenophora as a sister in all other animals is a statistical anomaly due to the rapid development of ctenophoric genome, and that Porifera (spongee) is, on the other hand, an early animal clot. Ctenophores and mushrooms are also the only known animal phyla with no real hox genes.

paragraphs.context: Since all current ctenophores except beroids have larvae such as cydippid, it has been widely assumed that their last common ancestor is also similar to cydippides with an egg-shaped body and a couple of retractable tentacles. A purely morphological analysis carried out by Richard Harbison in 1985 concluded that cydippides are not monophyletic, that is, they do not have all the offspring of one common ancestor, who was the cydippi. Instead, he found that different families of cydippies were more like members of other ctenofor regulations than other cydippids. He also suggested that the last common ancestor of current ctenophores should be either cydippid or beroid-type. A 2001 molecular phylogen analysis using 26 species, including four species recently discovered, confirmed that cydippids are not monophyletic and noted that the last common ancestor of modern ctenophores was similar to cydippid. It also found that the genetic differences between these species were very small — so small that the relationship between Lobata, Cestida and Thalassocalycida remained uncertain. This suggests that the last common ancestor of modern ctenophores was relatively fresh, and was perhaps lucky to survive the Cretaceous Paleogene extinction 65.5 million years ago when other families were destroyed. By extending the analysis to include representatives of other phylos, it concluded that clinicians are likely to be closer to the biltarists than either group is to the ctenophors, but that the diagnosis is uncertain.

paragraphs.context: The homes of the early 20th century border this boulevard in the heart of the historic Alta Vista Tract. The Huntington Boulevard area between First Street and Cedar Avenue westward is home to many large, handsome homes. The initial development of the area began around 1910 in 190 acres, which had been an alphafield. William Stranahan mapped Alta Vista Tract, as the country would become known, to the Pacific Improvement Company, and it was officially done in 1911. The borders of the tract were Balch Avenue in the south, Cedar Avenue in the east, Platt Avenue (Northeast) and Platt Avenue (Sixth Street) in the north and First Street in the west. The area was integrated into the city in January 1912 and was the first election in which women voted in the community. When Alta Vista Tract got into town, it was uninhabited, but landscaped, even though the trees had to be watered with a tankcar. In 1914, developers Billings & Meyering bought a tract, completed street development, provided the last necessary municipal improvements, including water supply, and began to market the property enthusiastically. paragraphs.context: In the northeast of Fresno Woodward Park was founded by the late Ralph Woodward, a long-time resident of Fresno. He left much of his property in 1968 to offer a park and bird sanctuary in northeastern Fresno. The park is located on the south bank of the San Joaquin river between highway 41 and Friant Road. The first 235 acres (0.95 km2) combined with the additional hectares later acquired by City bring the park to a large 300 acres (1.2 km2). Woodward Park is now full of comforts, and it is the only area park of its size in Central Valley. There are numerous bird species in the southeast corner of the park that offer bird enthusiasts an excellent opportunity to watch. The park has a multipurpose amphitheater that can accommodate up to 2,500 people, a genuine Japanese garden, a fenced dog park, three kilometres of riding route, a training par course, three children's playgrounds, a lake, three small ponds, seven picnic areas and eight kilometres of multipurpose trails, which are part of the Lewis S. Eaton Trail route of San Joaquin River Parkway. When the Lewis S. Eaton route system is complete, it will cover 35 kilometers between Highway 99 and Friant Dam. The numerous picnic tables in the park allow a fantastic picnic destination and a convenient escape from the city's life. The amphetamine factory in the park was renovated in 2010 and has hosted performances with presentations such as Deftones, Tech N9ne and Sevendust and numerous others. The park is open from April to October, 6-10 and from November to March, 6-7. A CIF (California Interscholastic Federation) competition will be held annually in Woodward Park, which will take place at the end of November. It is also the home of Woodward Shakespeare Festival, which started performing in the park in 2005.

paragraphs.context: Fresno is characterized by a semi-mature climate (Köppen BSh) with mild, moist winters and hot and dry summers, reflecting Mediterranean characteristics. December and January are the coldest months and averages about 46.5 °F (8.1 °C), and every year there are 14 nights by cold readings, and the coldest night of the year is typically less than 30 °C (-1,1 °C). July is the warmest month, with an average of 83.0 °C (28.3 °C); normally it is 32 days at 100 °C (37.8 °C) + high and 106 days at 90 °C (32.2 °C) + high, and in July and August it is only three or four days when high does not rise at 90 °C (32.2 °C). Summers provide some sunshine, and July peaks at 97 percent of all possible sunlight hours, and accordingly January is the lowest when daylight is only 46 percent due to a thick fog of fire. However, the year averages 81 percent of possible sunshine, for a total of 3550 hours. The average annual rainfall is approximately 292.1 millimetres, which would classify the area as a semi-desert. Most of the wind rises from the northwest as the winds are driven down the Central Valley axis of California. In December, in January-February, the wind rise statistics show more and more south-easterly directions. Fresno's meteorology was selected in a national study conducted by the US Environmental Protection Agency, which analysed the equilibrium temperature for the use of ten years of meteorological data, which represents a warm, dry local area of the West United States.

On average, windows 100 °F (37.8 °C)+, 90 °F (32.2 °C)+ and frosts are from 1 June to 13 September, from 26 April to 9 October and from 10 December to 28 January, and no frost occurred between 1983 and 1984. Between July 1982 and June 1983 the annual rainfall ranged from 598.7 cm between July 1933 and June 1934 to 4.43 cm (112.5 mm). paragraphs.context: There are three main types of stones: magnets, sediments and metamorphics. The rock cycle is an important concept of geology, which describes the relationship between these three types of rock and magma. When the stone crystallises by melting (magma and/or lava), it is a fine stone. This stone can be saved and dried, then stored and flattened into sedimentary stone, or transformed into a stone because of heat and pressure, which changes the mineral content of the rock, giving it a characteristic fabric. The sedimentary rock can then be transformed into a shape-shifting stone by heat and pressure, after which it is saved, decomposed, layered, and flattened and eventually transformed into a sedimentary stone. The sedimentary stone can also be plastered and stored again, and the metamorphic stone can also be changed. paragraphs.context: Newcastle dialect is known as Geordie and contains a large number of vocabulary and distinctive words that are not used elsewhere in the United Kingdom. The Geordi dialect is largely derived from the language spoken by the Anglo - Saxon population, which changed much of England and conquered much of England after the end of Roman imperial rule. This language was a pioneer in modern English, but although the dialects of other English areas have changed dramatically due to the influences of other foreign languages, especially Latin and Norman French, Geordi dialect contains many elements of the old language. An example of this is the saying of certain words: 'dead', 'cow', 'home' and'strong' are pronounced 'act', 'koo', 'hoo' and'strang' - that is how they were pronounced in Anglo-Saxon. Other Geordie words with an Anglo-Saxon origin are: "larn" (an Anglo-Saxon "laeran", meaning "teacher", "burn" ("stream") and "gan" ("go").

paragraphs.context: St Andrew's church has traditionally been recognized as "the oldest church in this city". The current building began its operations in the 12th century, and the last addition was the main porch in 1726, except for canned goods. It is quite possible that there was a previous church here from the days of Saxon. This older church would have been one of several churches along the Tyne River, dedicated to St Andrew, including the Hexham Monastery. The building contains more old stone works than any other church in Newcastle. It is surrounded by the last ancient church courts that retain their original character. Many key names related to Newcastle history were worshiped and buried here. During the siege of Newcastle, Scots were beaten into the church tower, which eventually invaded the city wall and forced surrender. Three cannonballs are still present as evidence of a siege.

paragraphs.context: Victoria and Albert Museum (often abbreviated to V&A), London, is the world’s largest museum of decorative art and design with a permanent collection of over 4.5 million objects. It was founded in 1852 and named after Queen Victoria and Prince Albert. V&A is located in the district of Brompton, the royal city of Kensington and Chelsea, known as Albertopolis, because it is connected with Prince Albert, Albert Memorial and the large cultural institutions to which he was in contact. These include the Museums of Natural History, the Museum of Science and Royal Albert Hall. The museum is a non-departmental public body supported by the Ministry of Culture, Media and Sport. Like other British national museums, the entrance to the museum has been free since 2001.

paragraphs.context: V&A covers 55,000 hectares (51,000 m2) and 145 galleries. Its collection covers 5,000 years of art from ancient times to modern times, from European, North American, Asian and North African cultures. Ceramics, glass, textiles, suits, silver, iron works, jewellery, furniture, medieval objects, sculptures, fingerprints and printed products, drawings and photographs are the largest and most comprehensive premises in the world. The museum owns the world's largest collection of post-classical sculptures, and the Italian Renaissance objects have the largest facilities outside Italy. Asian departments have art from South Asia, China, Japan, Korea and the Islamic world. East Asian collections are among the best in Europe and have special strengths in ceramics and metal work, while Islamic collection is one of the largest in the Western world. All in all, it is one of the largest museums in the world.

paragraphs.context: The roots of V&A are at the Great Exhibition of 1851, where Henry Cole, the first director of the museum, was involved in the design. Originally it was known as a manufacturing museum that was first opened in May 1852 at Marlborough House, but it had been moved to Somerset House by September. At this point, the collections covered both applied art and science. Several exhibits were acquired at the core of the collection. By February 1854 there was a debate on the transfer of the museum to the current site, and it was named the South Kensington Museum. In 1855 German architect Gottfried Semper produced a museum model at Cole’s request, but the commercial government rejected it as too expensive. Brompton Park House lived in the area and was extended to the first refreshment rooms opened in 1857. The museum is the first in the world to offer such a space.

paragraphs.context: The official opening of Queen Victoria was June 22, 1857. The following year a late - evening opening was introduced, which enabled the use of gas lighting. The purpose of this was, in Cole's words, 'to ensure in practice which hours are the most convenient for the working classes' - this related to the use of both applied art and scientific collections as teaching resources to promote productive industries. In these early years, the practical use of the collection was strongly emphasised, unlike the "high art" of the National Gallery and the British Museum scholarship. George Wallis (1811-1891), the first director of the Art Collection, was passionate about promoting the idea of extensive art education through museum collections. This led to the Museum of Design School of Design, founded in Somerset House in 1837. After the transfer it became an art school or art school that eventually gained full independence in 1949. The scientific collections had been moved from the 1860s to the 1880s from the museum's main site to various improvised galleries west of Exhibition Road. In 1893 the "Science Museum" was born in practice when a separate director was appointed.

paragraphs.context: The Victorian parts of the building have a complex history, and various architects have added them piece by piece. The museum, founded in May 1852, did not move to the current site until 1857. This area of London was known as Brompton, but it was called South Kensington. The land was occupied by Brompton Park House, which was expanded in particular by the Brompton Boilers, which were iron galleries that were used by the embroidery and were later dismantled and used to build the children’s V&A Museum. The first building still belonging to the museum was a gallery of sheepshanks built on the east side of the garden in 1857. Its architect was Captain Francis Fowke, a construction engineer appointed by Cole. The following major expansions were designed by the same architect, Turner and Vernon galleries in 1858-9 collections to build denominations (which were later transferred to Tate Gallery) and now used photo galleries and photo gallery. After that, the northern and southern courtyards were built, both of which were opened by June 1862. They now form galleries for temporary exhibitions and are directly behind Sheepshanks Gallery. On the north side of the area is located Secretariat Wing, which was also built in 1862 and has offices and meeting room etc. and is not open to the public.
