paragraphs.context: An ambitious decoration plan was developed in these new areas: a series of mosaic characters depicting the famous European artists of the Middle Ages and the Renaissance. They have now been moved to other areas of the museum. There were also Lord Leighton's fresco series: Industrial Arts, which has been applied to the war from 1878 to 1880 and Industrial Arts for Peace, which was started but never ended. On the east side there were more galleries decorated by another designer Owen Jones, the Oriental courts (including India, China and Japan) that were completed in 1863, and some of these galleries became the new galleries of the 19th century that were opened in December 2006. Fowke’s last work was the design of a selection of buildings north and west of the garden, including the refreshment rooms that were returned to the museum café in 2006, and the silver gallery above (when the ceramic gallery is located), on the top floor has a great lecture theatre, although this is rarely open to the general public. The ceramic staircase in the north-west corner of this series was designed by F. W. Moody and has architectural details of shaped and colored ceramics. All work in northern range was designed and built in 1864–69. The style of this part of the museum was Italian Renaissance, a lot of terracotta, brick and mosaic records were used, this northern facade was intended as the main door of the museum with James Gamble & Reuben Townroe bronze doors, and it had six panels: Humphry Davy (chemistry), Isaac Newton (astronomy), James Watt (mechanics), Bramante (architectist), Michelangelo ( sculpture), Titian (painting), representing the collection of museum collections, Godfrey Sykes also designed terracotta ornaments and mosaic in North Façade pedition, which recalled a great exhibition that helped finance the museum, and this is on Percival Ball’s terracotta group page. paragraphs.context: The interior of the three refreshment rooms was assigned to various designers. Green Dining Room 1866–68 was the work of Philip Webb and William Morris and presents Elizabeth’s influences. At the bottom of the walls there is a wooden panel with paintings of fruits and random characters. The main part of the wall is shaped mortar leaves and around the decorated roof of Edward Burne-Jones there are plastered freaks and glass paintings. The Centre Revirment Room 1865–77 is designed in Renaissance style by James Gamble, walls and even Ionic poles covered with decorative and shaped ceramic tiles, the roof consists of elaborate design of enamelled metal plates and custom glass paintings, designed and carved by Alfred Stevens, and was removed from Dorchester House before the building was demolished in 1929. Grill Room 1876–81 is designed by Sir Edward Poynter, which consists of blue and white tiles with different shapes and leaves closed with wooden panels. Above it are large tiles with four season figures, and for twelve months they painted the women of the art school who were then located in the museum, the windows are also colored glass, still have an elaborate cast iron grill.

paragraphs.context: After the death of Captain Francis Fowke of Royal Engineers, the next architect of the museum was Colonel (later Major General) Henry Young Darracott Scott, also Royal Engineers. He designed a five-story Navy architecture school (also known as science schools) northwest of the garden, now Henry Cole Wing in 1867-72. Scott’s assistant J.W. Wild designed an impressive stairwell made of Cadeby’s stone with a length of 2.1 meters, balustrades and columns for Portland stone. It is now used together to compile the printing and architectural drawings of the V&A (prints, drawings, paintings and photographs) and the Royal Institute of British Architects (RIBA Drawings and Archive Collections) and the Sackler Centre for Arts Education (Sackler Centre for Arts Education) opened in 2008.

Moody. The last decoration was the iron gates designed by Starkie Gardner, which led to the passage through the building. paragraphs.context: The main facade, built from the red brick and Portland stone, stretches 220 meters along Cromwell Gardens, and was designed by Aston Webb after winning in 1891 for the expansion of the museum. Construction took place between 1899 and 1909. Stylishly, it is a strange hybrid, although much of the detail belongs to the Renaissance, has medieval influences at work. The main entrance consists of a series of low arches, supported by thin columns and narrow fences, whose double doors are separated from the platform, and is in a Romanic form, but in detail classic. The tower above the main door also features an open work crown with a famous statue, a late feature of Gothic architecture and a common feature of Scotland, but the detail is Classical. The main windows of the galleries are also edited and transomized, while the Gothic feature. In the top row of the windows there are statues of many British artists whose work is displayed in the museum.

paragraphs.context: In the immediate postwar years, little money was available for other than necessary repairs. In the 1950s and early 1960s construction work was hardly visible; the first great work was the creation of new storage facilities for books at the Art Library in 1966 and 1967. This included paving the floor of Aston Webb's main hall to form stacks of books, and there was a new medieval gallery on the ground floor (now a store opened in 2006). Then, in 1978, new galleries covering continental art from 1600 to 1800 (later Renaissance, Baroque through Rocococo and New Clastic) were opened. In 1974 the museum had acquired the current Henry Cole wing at the Royal College of Science University. In order to transform the building into galleries, all Victorian interiors except the stairwell were renewed during the renovation. To connect it to the rest of the museum, a new entrance was built to the planned location of the former Spiral boilers between 1978 and 1982. This building is concrete and well-functioning, and the only beauty is the iron gates of Christopher Hay and Douglas Coyne from the Royal College of Art. paragraphs.context: In the 1990s, a number of galleries were redesigned, including Indian, Japanese, Chinese, iron works, main glass galleries and the main silver gallery, which was further improved in 2002 when part of the Victorian decoration was re-established. This included two out of ten columns with ceramic ornaments replaced, and elaborate painted designs were returned to the ceiling. As part of the 2006 renovation, the mosaic floors of the sculpture gallery were restored – most of the Victorian floors were covered with linoleum after World War II. After the success of the British Galleries galleries opened in 2001, it was decided to design all the galleries in the museum, known as FuturePlan, and it was created in collaboration with the designers and master designers of the exhibition, Metaphor. The plan is expected to last for about ten years and was launched in 2002. To date, several galleries have been redesigned, in particular in 2002: The main Silver Gallery, Contemporary; in 2003: Photography, main entrance, The Painting Galleries; in 2004: metro tunnel leading to South Kensington metro station, New sign in museum, architecture, V&A and RIBA reading rooms and shops, metal objects, members' room, contemporary glass, Gilbert Bayes sculpture gallery, in 2005: portraits in miniatures, prints and drawings, displays in room 117, garden, holy silver and colored glass, in 2006 in Central Hall Shop, Islamic Middle East, new café, sculptured galleries. paragraphs.context: V&A holds more than 19 000 objects from the Islamic world, ranging from the Islamic era (seventh century) to the early 20th century. The Jameel Gallery of Islamic Art, which was opened in 2006, has 400 items, the highlight of which is the Ardabil carpet, the central part of the gallery. The exhibition covers objects from Spain, North Africa, the Middle East, Central Asia and Afghanistan. The masterpiece of Islamic art is the Rock Crystal Ewer of the 100th century. There are many examples of al-Qur'aans with excellent calligraphy from different periods of time. The 16th-century Minbari of the mosque in Cairo, where ivory forms complex geometrical patterns of wood, is one of the largest exhibits on display. There are wide-ranging examples of ceramics, especially Iznik ceramics, glass works, including the 15th century lamps and metal works of mosques. The collection of Middle East and Persian carpets and carpets is one of the finest in the world, many were part of the 1909 Salting Bequest event. There are also examples of turquoise plates in various buildings, such as a fireplace from Istanbul in 1731, made from turquoise sheets of complexly decorated blue and white bricks and buildings outside Samarkand.

paragraphs.context: The museum’s art collections of Southeast and South-East Asia are the most comprehensive and significant in the Western world, with nearly 60 000 items, some 10,000 of which are textiles and 6,000 paintings. The collection’s selection is huge. The Jawaharllal Nehru Gallery of Indian Art, opened in 1991, contains art from around 500 BC to the 19th century. There is an extensive collection of sculptures, mainly religious, Hindu, Buddhist and jain. The gallery has a wealth of art from the Mughal Empire and the Marathons, such as fine portraits and other paintings and drawings of the emperors, jade wine cups and emeralds, diamonds and rubies decorated with gold spoons, which are also part of buildings, such as jaal and pillars. India was a major textile producer, made from dyed cotton cloth, from muslin to rich embroidery work with gold and silver yarn, colored sequins and pearls, as well as on the carpets of Agra and Lahore. There are also examples of clothing on display.

paragraphs.context: The collections in the Far East include over 70 000 works of art from East Asia: China, Japan and Korea. T. T. Tsui’s Chinese art gallery was opened in 1991 with a representative collection of video and video objects from China, dating back to the present day of 4 millenniums B.C.E. Although most of the artworks on display are from the Ming and Qing dynasty, there are excellent examples of Tang dynasty and previous seasons. Buddha’s three-foot - tall bronze head was timed to C.750 A.D. and one of the oldest objects, the 2,000 - year - old jade horse’s head from the tomb, other sculptures include grave guards of life - size. Classical examples of Chinese production are displayed, such as varnish, silk, porcelain, jade and closonné enamel. Two large portraits of an ancestor of a man and a wife painted in watercolor silk dates back to the 18th century. In the imperial workshops during the reign of the Emperor of Xuande, the Ming dynasty has a unique Chinese varnishing table. There are also examples of clothing on display. One of the finest items on display is Suzuki Chokichi’s bronze incense burner (koro), which dates from 1875 and stands more than 2,25 meters high and 1,25 meters in diameter, is also one of the greatest examples. paragraphs.context: One of the great treasures of the library is the Codex Forster, Leonardo da Vinci's notebooks. The codex consists of three parchment-bound manuscripts, Forster I, Forster II and Forster III, which have a relatively small size and date from 1490 to 1505. Their contents contain a large collection of sketches and references to the riding sculpture ordered by Duke Ludovico Sforza of Milan in memory of his father, Francesco Sforza. John Forster left these over 18,000 books at the museum in 1876. Pastor Alexander Dyce was another librarian who left over 14,000 books at the museum in 1869. Among the books he collected are the early editions of poets and playwrights Aeschelus, Aristotle, Homer, Livy, Ovid, Pindar, Sophocles, and Virgil in Greek and Latin. More recent authors include Giovanni Boccaccio, Dante, Racine, Rabelais and Molière.

paragraphs.context: Galleries also combine design with wider trends in British culture. For example, the design of the Tudor era was influenced by the proliferation of printed books and by the work of European artists and craftsmen working in Britain. During Stuart’s time, increasing trade, especially with Asia, allowed wider access to carpets, lacquered furniture, silk and porcelain. In the Georgian era, entertainment and leisure were increasingly emphasised. For example, the increase in tea drinking led to the production of tea grades such as porcelain and caps. The EM styles seen at the Grand Tour also affected the taste. When the industrial revolution began, the growth in mass production produced entrepreneurs, such as Josiah Wedgwood, Matthew Boulton and Eleanor Coade. In the Victorian era, new technology and machinery had a significant impact on production, and for the first time since the reform, the Anglican and Roman Catholic churches had a significant influence on art and design, such as the Gothic Revival. paragraphs.context: The conservation is responsible for the long-term preservation of the collections and covers all collections held by V&A and V&A Children’s Museum. Conservatorys specialise in certain protected areas. The work of the Conservator includes "preventive" protection measures, including surveys, assessments and advice on the handling of objects, correct packaging, installation and handling during movements, and evidence to reduce the risk of damaging objects. Activities include controlling the museum’s environment (e.g. temperature and light) and preventing pests (primarily insects) from harming objects. The second main category is "inventive" protection, including cleaning and readjustment to strengthen fragile objects, revealing the original surface decoration and restoring shape. Interventional treatment makes the object more stable, but also more attractive and understandable to the viewer. It is usually done in objects intended for public display.

paragraphs.context: Pathogens can rapidly develop and adapt, thus avoiding the detection and neutralisation of the immune system, but many defence mechanisms have also developed to identify and neutralize pathogens. Even simple unicellular organisms, such as bacteria, have a primitive immune system, which are enzymes that protect against bacteriophages. Other basic immune mechanisms of antiquity eukaryotics have developed and survived in their present offspring, such as plants and invertebrates. These mechanisms include phagocytosis, microbiological peptides called defensins and a complement system. Mutilated vertebrates, including humans, have more advanced defence mechanisms, including the ability to adapt over time to identify certain pathogens more effectively. Adaptive (or acquired) immunity creates an immunological memory after a response to a specific pathogen, leading to a better response to a later encounter with the same pathogen. paragraphs.context: Immunology is a science that studies the structure and functioning of the immune system. It comes from medical science and early studies to investigate the causes of immunity to diseases. The earliest known reference to immunity was at the time of the Athens plague in 430 B.C.E. Thucydides pointed out that those recovering from a previous seizure could treat the sick without getting sick again. In the 18th century Pierre-Louis Moreau de Maupertuis experimented with scorpion poison and found that certain dogs and mice were immune to this poison. Louis Pasteur used this and other observations about gaining immunity later on in his vaccination development and in his proposed bacterial disease theory. Pasteur's theory was in direct conflict with the theories of current diseases, such as the miasma theory. paragraphs.context: The immune system protects organisms from infections that have a layered, increasing specificity defence. If pathogens manage to avoid an inborn response, vertebrates have another protective layer, an adaptive immune system, which is activated by an inborn response. Here the immune system adapts its response during infection to improve the identification of the pathogen. paragraphs.context: Inflammation is one of the first infections in the immune system. Symptoms of inflammation include redness, swelling, heat and pain due to increased blood flow to tissues. Inflammation is caused by eicosanoids and cytokines released by injured or infected cells. Eikosanoids include prostaglandins, which cause dilation of blood vessels that cause fever and inflammation, as well as leukotrienes that attract certain white blood cells (leukocytes). Common cytokines are interleukins responsible for communication between white blood cells, chemokines that promote chemotax, and interferons with antiviral effects such as stopping protein synthesis in the host cell. Growth factors and cytotoxic factors may also be released. paragraphs.context: Neutrophils and macrophages are phagocytes that travel throughout the body in pursuit of aggressive pathogens. During the acute inflammatory phase, especially as a result of bacterial infection, neutrophils are transferred towards the site of inflammation in a process called chemotaxia and are usually the first cells to arrive at the site of infection. Macrophages are diverse cells that live in tissues and produce a wide range of chemicals such as enzymes, complement proteins and regulating factors such as interleukin 1. Macrophages also act as scavengers that remove worn-out cells and other scraps from the body as well as antigen-present cells that activate the adaptive immune system.

paragraphs.context: Natural killer cells, or NK cells, are a part of a natural immune system that does not directly attack the attacking microbes. Instead, NK cells destroy damaged host cells, such as cells that cause tumour cells or viral infections, and identify such cells in a farm called "lost self". This term refers to cells with a low cell surface stamp MHC I (high histocompatibility complex) – a situation that may arise in host cell viral infections. They were named "natural killer" because they didn't originally need activation to kill cells that "disappear themselves". For many years it was unclear how NK cells identified tumour cells and infected cells. Now it is known that the MHC makeup on the surface of these cells changes and the NK cells activate by identifying the "missing self". NK cells do not recognise and attack normal body cells because they express intact MHC antigens. Those MHC antigens recognize the immunoglobulin receptors (KIRs) of the killer cell, which mainly inhibit NK cells.

paragraphs.context: The adaptive immune system developed in early vertebrates and allows for a stronger immune response and immunological memory, where each pathogen is "remembered" by an identification antigen. The adaptive immune response is antigen specific and requires the identification of certain "non-selfish" antigens in the presence of antigens. Antigen specificity allows for the production of responses tailored to specific pathogens or pathogen-infected cells. The ability to install these customized responses remains in the body with "memory cells". If the pathogen infects the body more than once, these special memory cells are used to quickly remove it.

paragraphs.context: Both B and T cells carry receptor molecules that identify specific targets. T-cells only identify a "non-self" target, such as a pathogen, after treatment and presentation of antigens (small pieces of pathogen) together with a "self-self" receptor called a significant histocompatibility complex (MHC). There are two main types of T-cells: the killer T-cell and the helper T-cell. In addition, there are regulated T-cells that are relevant to the modification of the immune response. Killer T-cells only recognise antigens associated with IHC molecules, while helper T-cells and regulating T-cells only identify antigens associated with Class II MHC molecules. These two antigen presentations reflect the different roles of the two types of T-cells. A third minor subtype is T-cells that identify intact antigens that do not bind to MHC receptors.

paragraphs.context: Killer T-cells are sub-group T-cells that kill infected or otherwise damaged or incapacitated cells with viruses (and other pathogens). Like B-cells, each type of T-cell recognizes a different antigen. Killer T-cells are activated when their T-cell receptor (TCR) binds to this specific antigen in a complex with a second cell MHC class I receptor. The recognition of this MHC antigen complex is supported by the T-cell's second receptor, CD8. The T-cell then travels throughout the body looking for cells in which MHC I receptors carry this antigen. When an activated T-cell contacts such cells, it releases cytotoxics, such as perforin, which form pores in the target cell plasma membrane, allowing ions, water and poisons to enter. The transfer of another toxin (protease) called granulysin causes target cell apoptosis. Killing T-cells in host cells is particularly important in preventing viral reproduction. T-cell activation is strictly controlled and usually requires a very strong MHC/antigen activation signal or additional activation signals given by the "helper" T-cells (see below).

paragraphs.context: Helicopter T-cells express T-cell receptors that identify a antigen bound to Class II MHC molecules. The MHC antigen complex is also identified by the helper cell CD4 combination receptor, which recruits molecules (e.g. Lck) responsible for T-cell activation. Helicopter T cells have a weaker connection to the MHC antigen complex than killer T cells, which means that many T-cell receptors (about 200-300) of the adjutant cell must be bound to the MHC antigen in order to activate the adjutant cell, while the T-cells of the killer can be activated by a single MHC antigen molecule. The activation of the Heliper T cell also requires a longer period of time with the antigen-presenting cell. The activation of the T-cell by the rest-assisted device causes it to release cytokines that affect the function of many cell types. Cytokine signals produced by assistant T-cells enhance the microbial activity of macrophages and the activity of killer T-cells. In addition, helper T cell activation increases the regulation of molecules on the surface of the T-cell, such as CD40 ligand (also called CD154), providing additional stimulatory signals typically needed to activate antibodies-producing B cells.

paragraphs.context: Gammadelta T-cells (T-cells) have an alternative T-cell receptor (TCR) against CD4+ and CD8+ cells and have the properties of T-cells, cytotoxic T-cells and NK cells. The conditions for T-cell response are not fully understood. Like other "unconventional" T-cells with invariant TCR cells, such as CD1d-limited Natural Killer T-cells, including T-cells, run at the limit of congenital and adaptive immunity. On the other hand, T-cells are part of an adaptive immunity when they modify TCR genes to produce receptor diversity and can also develop a phenotype of memory. On the other hand, different subgroups are also part of the congenital immune system, since limited TCR or NK receptors can be used as pattern recognition receptors. For example, a large number of human V.9/V.2 T-cells respond within hours to the usual molecules produced by microbes, and very limited V.1+ T-cells react to stressed epithelial cells in epithelial cells.

paragraphs.context: A B cell identifies pathogens when antibodies on its surface bind to a specific foreign antigen. This antigen/antibody complex is transferred to the B cell and treated with proteolysis as peptides. The B cell then contains these antigen peptides in MHC class II molecules. This combination of MHC and antigen attracts a suitable helper T cell that releases lymphokins and activates the B cell. When the activated B cell then begins to divide, its offspring (plasma cells) secrete millions of copies of the antibody that recognizes this antigen. These antibodies circulate in plasma and lymph nodes, bind to antigen-expressing pathogens and indicate that they are destroyed by complement activation or into the uptake and destruction of phagocytes. Antibodies can also neutralise challenges directly, by binding to bacterial poisons or by interfering with receptors used by viruses and bacteria to infect cells.

paragraphs.context: When B and T cells become activated and multiply, some of their offspring become long-lived memory cells. Throughout the life of the animal, these memory cells remember every pathogen they encounter and may have a strong response if the pathogen is re-occurred. This is "adaptable" because it occurs during the lifetime of the individual as an adaptation to the infection caused by the pathogen and prepares the immune system for future challenges. Immunological memory can be either in the form of passive short-term memory or active long-term memory.

paragraphs.context: New-born children have no prior exposure to microbes and are particularly susceptible to infection. Mother has several layers of passive protection. During pregnancy, a certain type of antibody, IgG, passes directly from the mother to the child through the placenta, so that human babies have high levels of antibodies even at birth, and the differences in antigens are the same as the mother. Breast milk or colostrum also contains antibodies that pass into the intestines of the infant and protect against bacterial infections until the newborn can synthesize its own antibodies. This is a passive immunity because the fetus does not actually make memory cells or antibodies, but simply borrow them. This passive immunity is usually of short duration and lasts for a few days to several months. Passive immunity that protects medicine can also be artificially transferred from one individual to another by means of an antibody-containing serum.

paragraphs.context: Hormones can act as immunomodulators, which alters the sensitivity of the immune system. For example, female sex hormones are immunostimulators of both anadaptive and congenital immune responses. Some autoimmune diseases, such as lupus erythematosus, primarily strike women, and their onset often occurs at the same time as puberty. In contrast, male sex hormones, such as testosterone, appear to be immunosuppressive. Other hormones also appear to regulate the immune system, especially prolactin, growth hormone and vitamin D.

paragraphs.context: It has been thought that the progressive reduction in hormone levels with age is partly the cause of a weakened immune response in older people. On the other hand, the immune system regulates some hormones, especially thyroid hormone. Age-related immune impairment is also associated with decreased vitamin D levels in the elderly. As people age, there are two things that have a negative effect on their vitamin D levels. First of all, they remain indoors more because of the fall in activity levels. This means that they receive less sun and thus produce less cholecalciferol through UVB radiation. Secondly, as humans age, the skin is no longer as good at producing vitamin D.

paragraphs.context: The immune system primarily responds to tumours by destroying abnormal cells with killer T cells, sometimes with helper T cells. Tumour antigens are present in MHC class I molecules in the same way as viral antigens. This is how the killer's T-cells identify the tumor cell as abnormal. NK cells also kill tumour cells in the same way, especially if the tumour cells contain fewer MHC class I molecules than normal; this is a common tumour phenomenon. Sometimes antibodies are created against tumour cells, which allows them to be destroyed in the complement system.

paragraphs.context: Unlike animals, plants do not have phagocytic cells, but many plant immune responses are accompanied by systemic chemical signals that are transmitted through the plant. Individual plant cells react to pathogens called pathogen-related molecular models or PAMP models. When part of the plant becomes infected, the plant produces a local hypersensitivity response in which the cells at the site of infection quickly enter apoptosis to prevent the spread of the disease to other parts of the plant. Systemic acquired resistance (SAR) is a plant defence response that makes the whole plant resistant to a specific infectious agent. RNA silencing mechanisms are particularly important in this systemic response as they may inhibit viral replication.

paragraphs.context: Overactive immune responses are the other end of the immune disorder, especially autoimmune diseases. Here the immune system cannot properly distinguish itself and itself and attack part of the body. Under normal circumstances, many T-cells and antibodies react with "self-reacted" peptides. One of the functions of specialised cells (located in the thymus and bone marrow) is to present young lymphocytes with the full body-produced antigens themselves, and to eliminate cells that identify themselves with antigens and inhibit autoimmunity.

paragraphs.context: Immunodeficiencies occur when one or more components of the immune system are inactive. The immune system’s ability to react to pathogens is impaired in both young and elderly patients, and the immune response begins to decline at about 50 years of age due to immunosensation. In developed countries, obesity, alcoholism and drug abuse are common causes of a weak immune system. However, malnutrition is the most common cause of immune deficiency in developing countries. Insufficient protein intake is associated with reduced cell-mediated immunity, complement activity, phagocyte activity, IgA antibody levels and cytokine production. In addition, early loss of thymus as a result of genetic mutation or surgical removal results in severe immunodeficiency and high susceptibility to infection.

paragraphs.context: Long-term active memory is obtained after infection by activating B and T cells. Active immunity can also be created artificially, through vaccination. The principle of vaccination (also called immunisation) is to introduce antigen from a pathogen to stimulate the immune system and develop specific immunity against that pathogen without causing any disease associated with that organism. This conscious immune response induction is successful because it utilizes the natural specificity of the immune system and its incubity. Infectious disease is still one of the most common causes of death in the human population, so vaccination is mankind’s most effective manipulation of the immune system.

paragraphs.context: The success of any pathogen depends on its ability to avoid an immune response. Therefore, pathogens developed several methods to infect the host while avoiding the detection or destruction of the immune system. Bacteria often overcome physical barriers by the excretion of enzymes that digest the barrier, for example by using the Type II secretion system. Alternatively, using the Type III secretion system, they can insert a hollow tube into the host cell, allowing the proteins to pass directly from the pathogen to the host cell. These proteins are often used to close the host defense.

paragraphs.context: In the mid-1950s Frank Burnet formulated Niels Jerne's proposal inspired by the Clonal Selection theory (CST) of immunity. Based on CST, Burnet developed a theory of how the immune response triggers itself and itself: "self-contained" components (body parts) do not trigger destructive immune responses, while "non-self-self-contained" communities (pathogens, allograft) trigger a destructive immune response. Later, the theory was modified to reflect new findings on histocompatibility or the complex activation of the "two characters" of T cells. The self-/non-self-theory of immunity and self-self-absorbing has been criticised, but it is still very influential.

paragraphs.context: Anti-inflammatory drugs are often used to control the effects of inflammation. Glucocorticoids are the most effective of these medicines. However, these medicines may have many unwanted side effects such as central obesity, hyperglycaemia, osteoporosis, and their use should be strictly controlled. Lower doses of NSAIDs are often used in combination with cytotoxic or immunosuppressive medicines such as methotrexate or azathioprine. Cytotoxic medicines inhibit the immune response by killing dividing cells, such as activated T cells. However, killing is random, and other cells and their organs that continue to divide are suffering, causing toxic side effects. Immunosuppressants, such as cyclosporin, prevent T cells from responding correctly to signals by blocking the transduction pathways of the signal.

In active times, anti-inflammatory molecules such as cortisol and catecholamines are at their peak. There are two theories as to why an inflammatory space is reserved for bedtime. For one thing, inflammation would cause serious cognitive and physical disturbances if it occurred during the waking hours. Secondly, inflammation may occur during sleep due to the presence of melatonin. Inflammation causes a lot of oxidative stress, and the presence of melatonin in sleeptimes can actively prevent free radical production during this period.

This is mainly a signal device that allows the T-cell to bind to the active vitamin D form of steroid hormone calcitriol. T-cells have a symbiotic relationship with vitamin D. The T-cell not only expands the vitamin D receptor, which basically asks to bind to the steroid hormone version of vitamin D, calcitriol, but the T-cell expresses the gene CYP27B1, which is the gene responsible for converting vitamin D pre-hormone version, calcidiol, into a steroid hormone version, calcitriol. paragraphs.context: The development of an adaptive immune system occurred in the progeny of the jaws. Many of the classic molecules of the adaptive immune system (e.g. immunoglobulins and T-cell receptors) are only in the jaw. However, in primitive leukocyte-free vertebrates, such as the lamp and hamburger, a separate molecule is identified by lymphocytes. These animals have a wide range of molecules called variable lymphocyte receptors (VLRs) and, like jaw-refractory antigen receptors, they are produced from only a few genes. These molecules are believed to bind pathogenic antigens in the same way as antibodies and with the same specificity.

paragraphs.context: It is likely that a multi-component, adaptive immune system was created with the first vertebrates, since invertebrates do not produce lymphocytes or an antibody-based humoral response. However, many species use mechanisms that appear to be precursors of vertebrate immunity. The immune system even exists in structurally the simplest forms of life, where bacteria use a unique defense mechanism called a restricted modification system to protect against viral pathogens called bacteriophages. Procaryotes also have acquired immunity through a system that uses CRISPR sequences to preserve fragments of previously contacted phage genomes that can prevent viral replication in the form of RNA disorder. Single cell eukaryotes also contain offensive elements of the immune system, but their defence roles have been studied little.

paragraphs.context: Immunology is strongly experimental in practice, but it is also characterised by a continuous theoretical attitude. There have been many theories in immunology from the late 19th century to the present. At the end of the 19th century and at the beginning of the 20th century, there was a struggle between "cellular" and "humoral" immunity theories. In particular, according to the theory of immunity of the cell represented by Elie Metchnikoff, the cells that responded to the immune response — more specifically, phagocytes. Instead, the humorous immunity theory of Robert Koch and Emil von Behring found that active immune agents were soluble components (molecules) observed in organisms that were not its cells.

Some tumour cells also release anti-immune products, such as the secretion of cytokine TGF-β, which suppresses the activity of macrophages and lymphocytes. In addition, immune tolerance can develop against tumour antigens, so the immune system no longer attacks tumour cells.

paragraphs.context: Hypersensitivity is an immune response that damages your body’s own tissues. They are divided into four categories (type I – IV) based on the mechanisms and timing of the hypersensitivity reaction. Type I hypersensitivity is an immediate or anaphylactic reaction, often associated with an allergy. Symptoms may vary from mild discomfort to death. Type I hypersensitivity is mediated by IgE, which triggers the degranulation of mast cells and basophils in cross-links with antigen. Type II hypersensitivity occurs when antibodies bind to the patient’s own cells antigens, which means their destruction. This is also called antibody-dependent (or cytotoxic) hypersensitivity and is mediated by IgG and IgM antibodies. Immune complexes in different tissues (aggregations of antigens, complement proteins, IgG and IgM antibodies) trigger type III hypersensitivity reactions. Type IV hypersensitivity (also known as cell-mediated or delayed type hypersensitivity) usually develops within two to three days. Type IV reactions are related to many autoimmune and infectious diseases, but may also be associated with contact dermatitis (toxic ivy). Reactions are transmitted to T cells, monocytes and macrophages.

paragraphs.context: The rotational strategy used by several pathogens to avoid a congenital immune system is to hide in the cells of their host cells (also called intracellular pathogenesis). Here the pathogen spends most of its life cycle in host cells, where it protects itself from direct contact with immune cells, antibodies and complements. Some examples of intracellular pathogens are viruses, food poisoning bacteria Salmonella and eukaryotic parasites that cause malaria (Plasmodium falciparum) and leishmaniasis (Leishmania spp.). Other bacteria, such as Mycobacterium tuberculosis, live inside a protective capsule, which prevents replenishment. Many pathogens secrete compounds that damage or misdirect the host’s immune response. Some bacteria form biofilms to protect the immune system from cells and proteins. Such biofilms occur in many successful infections, such as chronic infections with cystic fibrosis called Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Burkholder cenocepacia. Other bacteria produce surface proteins that bind to and render antibodies ineffective, such as Streptococcus (protein G), Staphylococcus aureus (protein A) and Peptostreptococcus magnus (protein L).

paragraphs.context: The mechanisms used to avoid an adaptive immune system are more complex. The simplest way is to quickly change the non-essential epitope on the surface of the pathogen (amino acids and/or sugars) while keeping the necessary epitopes hidden. This is called antigenic variation. An example is HIV, which is rapidly transformed, so the proteins in its virus shell that are necessary to get into its host cell are constantly changing. These repeated changes in antigens may explain the failure of vaccines directed at this virus. The parasite Trypanosoma brucei uses a similar strategy, constantly changing the surface protein type to another, allowing it to stay one step ahead of the antibody response. Covering antigens with host molecules is another common strategy to avoid the detection of the immune system. In HIV, the envelope that covers the virus consists of the outer membrane of the host cell; such "self-covering" viruses make it difficult for the immune system to identify them as "non-self-contained" structures.

paragraphs.context: Another important role in the immune system is the identification and removal of tumours. This is called immune control. The altered cells in the tumors express antigens that are not found in normal cells. For the immune system, these antigens appear to be foreign, and their presence causes immune cells to attack transformed tumour cells. Tumour-expressed antigens have several sources, some of which are derived from oncogen viruses, such as human papillomavirus, which causes cervical cancer, while others are the body’s own proteins that occur at low concentrations in normal cells but reach high tumour cell levels. One example is an enzyme called thyrosinase which, expressed at high concentrations, converts certain skin cells (e.g. melanocytes) into melanomas. A third potential source of tumour antigens is proteins, which are usually important for controlling cell growth and survival, and are usually converted into cancer-inducing molecules called oncogens.

paragraphs.context: Higher medicinal products (> 500 Da) may cause a neutralising immune response, especially when repeated or higher doses are administered. This limits the effectiveness of medicinal products based on higher peptides and proteins (typically greater than 6000 Da). In some cases, the medicine itself is not immunogenic but may be administered concomitantly with an immunogenic compound, as sometimes with Taxol. Calculation methods have been developed to predict the immunogenicity of peptides and proteins, as they are particularly useful in the design of therapeutic antibodies, the assessment of the likely virulence of mutations in viral layer particles and the validation of proposed peptide-based medicinal products. Early techniques were mainly based on the observation that hydrophilic amino acids are over-represented in epitopes as hydrophobic amino acids. However, recent developments are based on machine learning techniques using existing known epitope databases, usually based on well-researched viral proteins. A database has been set up to list epitope of pathogens known to be identified by B cells. The evolving field of immunogenicity studies based on bioinformatics is called immunoinformation. Immunoproteomics are used to study large proteins (proteomides) involved in immune response.

paragraphs.context: In humans, this response is activated when antibodies to microbes complement each other or when complement proteins bind to carbohydrates on the surface of microbes. This identification signal triggers a rapid kill response. The response rate is the result of the signal strengthening of the complex molecules, which are also protease, as a result of successive proteolytic activation. When initially bonded to a microbe, complement proteins activate their protease activity, which in turn activates other complement proteins and so on. This produces a catalyst that strengthens the initial signal with controlled positive feedback. Cascade produces peptides that attract immune cells, increase vascular permeability, and opsonize the pathogen’s surface, which means its destruction. This complement formation can also kill cells directly by interfering with their plasma membrane.

It has been used in many non-violent resistance movements in India (Gandh’s campaigns to become independent of the British Empire), in Czechoslovakia’s velvet revolution and in East Germany to overthrow Communist regimes in South Africa in the fight against apartheid, in the US civil rights movement, in the singing revolution that will bring the Baltic States to independence from the Soviet Union, recently with the 2003 Rose Revolution in Georgia and the 2004 Orange Revolution in Ukraine, including around the world.

paragraphs.context: After the Peterloo massacre in 1819, the poet Percy Shelley later wrote the political poem The Mask of Anarchy, which begins with pictures of what he considered to be the unjust form of authority of his day – and then imagines a revival of new social activity. It may be the first modern [unusual] statement on the principle of non-violent protest. Writer Henry David Thoreau introduced the version in his essay Civil Disobedience and later Gandhi Satyagrava. Gandhi’s Satyagrau was partly influenced by Shelley’s non-violence and political action. It is known in particular that Gandhi often lent Shelley's mask from anarchy to a wide audience during the campaign, free on behalf of India.

As originally written, the Daleks and the Thais were the victims of an alien neutron bomb attack, but later Nation dropped the aliens and turned the Daleks into attackers. When the manuscript was presented to Newman and Wilson, it was immediately rejected because the program was not allowed to contain any "eye eggs". The first series was finished, and BBC thought it was crucial that the next series were successful, but Mutants was the only completed script, so the program had no choice but to use it. According to producer Verity Lambert: "We didn't have much choice – we only had the Dalek series left." We had a slight lack of confidence because Donald [Wilson] was so unshakable that we should not get there. If we had anything else ready, we would have done it." paragraphs.context: In the 1890s, the University of Chicago feared that its vast resources would harm smaller schools by attracting good students from several regional universities and universities: Des Moines College, Kalamazoo College, Butler University and Stetson University. In 1896 the University joined Shimer College in Mount Carroll, Illinois. According to the terms of the association, schools had to have courses comparable to the university, notify the university in advance of any planned faculty meetings or layoffs, not book a faculty without the approval of the university, and send copies of the tests for proposals. The University of Chicago agreed to give a degree to all university graduates who completed an A degree for four years and to all other graduates who completed 12 weeks of additional studies at the University of Chicago. At the University of Chicago, a student or a member of the faculty was entitled to a free tuition fee, and Chicago students were entitled to attend the same school on the same terms and to receive recognition for their work. The University of Chicago also agreed to offer books and scientific equipment and supplies at any cost to schools, special teachers and lecturers without expenses except travel expenses, and a copy of each book and magazine published by the University of Chicago free of charge. The Agreement provides that both parties may terminate the bond in an appropriate manner. Several professors at the University of Chicago did not like the program because it included unpaid additional labor, and they believed that it devalued the university’s academic reputation. The program moved to history by 1910.

paragraphs.context: The system of bureaucracy created by Kublai Khan reflected the various cultures of the empire, such as Han-Chinese, Khitanic, Jurchen, Mongols and Tibetan Buddhists. However, the actual tasks of both central and local government institutions showed that civil and military rights are seriously overlapping, since the Mongol has traditionally relied on military institutions and agencies as the core of the regime. paragraphs.context: Many religions, such as Buddhism, Islam, and Christianity, were practiced during the Yuan dynasty. Since the Kublai Khan appreciated only the Sakya sect of Tibetan Buddhism, other religions became less important. He and his followers kept Sakya Imperial Preceptor (Dishi) in court. paragraphs.context: The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) is a scientific intergovernmental body under the auspices of the UN established at the request of the Member States. It was first established in 1988 by two UN organisations, the World Meteorological Organisation (WMO) and the UN Environment Programme (UNEP), and later adopted by the United Nations General Assembly by Resolution 43/53. IPCC membership is open to all WMO and UNEP members. The IPCC produces reports supporting the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC), which is the most important international climate agreement. The ultimate objective of the UNFCCC is to “stabilise greenhouse gas concentrations in the atmosphere to a level that would prevent a dangerous man-made [man-made] disturbance in the climate system”. The IPCC reports cover "scientific, technical and socio-economic information relevant to the risk of man-made climate change, its potential impacts and the understanding of adaptation and mitigation options".

paragraphs.context: A prime number (or prime number) is a natural number greater than 1 and with no other positive divisors than one and itself. paragraphs.context: Modern criteria for generic numbers n can be divided into two main categories, probabilistic (or "Monte Carlo") and deterministic algorithm. Determinist algorithms allow you to know for sure whether a given number is primary or not. For example, the trial section is a deterministic algorithm because, when properly performed, it always identifies the early century as a prime number and a combination of a combination number. Probable algorithms are usually faster, but do not fully prove that the figure is the best possible. These tests are based partly on random testing of a given number. For example, a specific test may pass all the time if used for the initial number, but it only passes with probability p if used for the combination number. If we repeat the test n times and pass every time, the probability that our number is a composite is 1/(1-p), which calculates exponentially with the number of tests, so we can be as sure as we want (though never completely sure) that the number is prime. On the other hand, if the test ever fails, we know that the number is a composite.

paragraphs.context: For the next three hundred years, Scotland was ruled directly by the British Parliament and its subsequent British Parliament, both sitting in Westminster, and the absence of the Scottish Parliament was still an important part of Scotland's national identity. Proposals for a 'decentralised' Parliament were made before 1914, but they were suspended because of the outbreak of World War I. The sharp rise of nationalism in Scotland in the late 1960s fueled demands for some kind of home government or complete independence, and in 1969 the current Labour Government of Harold Wilson set up the Kilbrandon Commission to consider the British Constitution. One of the main objectives of the Commission was to explore ways of increasing Scottish self-government in the United Kingdom. In 1973 Kilbrandon published a report recommending the creation of a directly elected Scottish Assembly to legislate for most of Scotland’s domestic affairs.

paragraphs.context: The Scottish Government is the party or party with the majority of seats in Parliament. Unlike many other parliamentary systems, Parliament elects the Prime Minister from several candidates at the beginning of each parliamentary term (after the general elections). Any Member may present his or her name as Prime Minister, and all Members of this House shall vote on it. Normally, the leader of the largest party will be returned to the Prime Minister and to the head of the Scottish Government. In theory, Parliament also elects the Scottish ministers, who form the Scottish Government and sit on the Scottish Government, but in practice these ministers are appointed by the Prime Minister. Younger ministers who do not participate in the government are also appointed to assist Scottish ministers in their ministries. Most of the ministers and their juniors come from chosen masters of the sea, except for the Scottish lawyers: Lord Advocate and Solicitor General. In addition to the ordinary parliamentary elections, there will be additional parliamentary elections unless they are less than six months before the scheduled date for the ordinary parliamentary elections, when they will replace them. paragraphs.context: "The word "empire" comes from the Latin word empire, for which the closest modern English equivalent might be "supermenity", or simply "rule". The greatest difference in the empire is the number of countries that have been conquered and expanded by the nation. Political power grew from conquering the country, but cultural and economic considerations flourished through maritime and trade routes. The difference between the kingdoms is that "although political empires were built mostly by expanding across the country, economic and cultural effects are spread at least as much by sea". Some of the main features of foreign trade consisted of animals and plant products. The European empires of Asia and Africa "have become seen as classic forms of imperialism, and most of the books on the subject are confined to the European maritime kingdoms". The expansion of Europe caused the world to divide according to how a developed and developing country is pictured through the world’s system theory. The two main areas are the core and the periphery. The core consists of large income and profit areas; the peripheral region is on the opposite side of the field, consisting of low-income and profit-oriented regions. These critical theories of geopolitics have increased the debate on the importance of imperialism and the impact on the modern post-colonial world. The Russian leader, Lenin, argued that 'imperialistism was the highest form of capitalism and claimed that imperialism developed after colonialism and was separated from colonialism by monopoly capitalism'. This idea of Lenin highlights the importance of the new political world order in our modern day. Geopolitics are now focusing on the fact that countries become major economic players in the market, some of which are now regarded as a nation because they have political and economic power over other countries.

paragraphs.context: The term 'imperialism' is often confused with 'colonialism', but many researchers have claimed that everyone has a clear definition of their own. Imperialism and colonialism have been used to describe man’s superiority, supremacy and influence on man or group of people. Robert Young writes that, although imperialism works from the centre, it is a state policy and is being developed for ideological and economic reasons, colonialism is only a development of colonial and commercial intentions. Colonialism in modern use also tends to imply a certain geographical difference between the colony and the imperial power. In particular, Edward Said distinguishes between imperialism and colonialism by saying that 'imperialism involves 'truth, theory and attitudes that dominate the metropolitan centre that dominates a remote area', while colonialism refers to 'the planting of settlements in a distant area'. The adjacent empires, such as Russia or the Ottoman, are usually excluded from colonial discussions.:116 It can therefore be said that imperialism contains some kind of colonialism, but colonialism itself does not automatically mean imperialism because it lacks political attention.[An additional explanation is needed]

paragraphs.context: Imperialism and colonialism dictate both political and economic interests over the country and the indigenous people they control, but it is sometimes difficult for researchers to illustrate the difference between the two. Although imperialism and colonialism focus on the repression of one another, if colonialism suggests that the country takes control of the other physically, imperialism refers to political and monetary power either formally or informally. Colonialism is seen to be an architect who decides how to begin to control the territories, and then imperialism can be seen as creating an idea behind colonial co-operation. Colonialism is when the imperial nation begins to conquer the territory and is finally able to control the territories ruled by the previous nation. The central meaning of colonial power is to exploit the valuable property and supplies of the conquered nation and to make the conquering nation benefit from the spoils of war. The purpose of imperialism is to create an empire by conquering the countries of another country and thereby increasing its own power. Colonial power is the builder and preserver of colonial property in the territory of the population coming from a foreign region. Colonism can completely change the existing social structure, physical structure and economy of the region. paragraphs.context: In Anglophonic academic works, theories of imperialism are often based on British experience. Opponents of the alleged aggressive and haughty imperialist policy of British Prime Minister Benjamin Disrael originally brought the term 'imperialism' to English in the late 1870s. Soon, supporters of imperialism, such as Joseph Chamberlain, caught it. To some, imperialism showed politics of idealism and goodwill, to others political selfishness, and more and more linked it to capitalist greed. Liberal John A. Hobson and Marxist Vladimir Lenin added a more theoretical macroeconomic mindset to the term. Lenin, in particular, had a significant influence on the later Marxist imperialist concepts of Imperialism, the highest stage of capitalism. Lenin described imperialism in his article as a natural extension of capitalism, which arose from the need for capitalist economies to continuously expand investment, material resources and labour in a way that required the expansion of the colonial region. Later Marxist theorists echo this notion of imperialism as a structural feature of capitalism. Many theorists on the left have followed the structural or systemic nature of imperialism. Such writers have extended the term-related era so that it does not now mean politics or a short space of decades at the end of the 19th century, but a world system that extends centuries away and often returns to Christopher Columbus and, in some cases, to the Crusades. Once the use of the term has expanded, its significance has shifted to five distinct but often parallel axes: morality, economy, system, culture and time. These changes reflect, among other things, changes in sensuality, growing unrest, even clammy, accompanied by a fact of power, especially of Western power.

paragraphs.context: The weak force is due to the exchange of heavy W and Z-bosons. Its most known effect is the breakdown of beta (neutrons of atomic nucleins) and the associated radioactivity. The word "weak" is derived from the fact that field strength is about 1013 times lower than strong force. However, it is stronger than gravity in short distances. In addition, a consistent electroweak theory has been developed showing that electromagnetic and weak forces are inseparable at temperatures above 1015 Kelvin. Such temperatures have been studied in modern particle accelerators and show the conditions of the universe at the early moments of the Big Bang.

paragraphs.context: In certain physical scenarios, it is impossible to model forces because of the slope of potentials. This is often due to macrophysical considerations that produce forces generated by the macroscopic statistical average of the micro-states. For example, the friction is due to the slopes of several electrostatic possibilities between atoms, but it appears as a power model that is not independent of any macro-scan position vector. Other than conservative forces than friction are other contact forces, tension, compression and stretching. However, for a sufficiently detailed description, all these forces are the results of conservative forces, since each of these macroscopic forces is the net result of microscopic gradients.

paragraphs.context: The weight of the pound is a metric equivalent less than the weight of the newton: kg (kgf) (sometimes kilopond) is the force obtained by the standard gravity of one kilogram of mass. The force of the weight kg leads to an alternative but rarely used mass unit: a metre bullet (sometimes a cup or casing) is the mass which accelerates 1 m·s−2 when subjected to a force of 1 kgf. Gravity is not part of the modern SI system and is generally degraded, but it nevertheless considers the use for some purposes to be an expression of aircraft weight, jet thrust, wheel talk, torque and engine torque.
